Object Title: Wind and navigation calculator Mk.II, 1935 - 1945
Calculator, Wind and Navigation, Mk.II, metal, unknown maker, c. 1940 This is a slide rule of metal construction. On the front is a conventional circular slide rule for time/distance calculations, and scales for determining true height and airspeed from observed values using ICAN calibration. On the reverse is a wind vector calculator. This is a mechanical calculator for bombsight calculations. It is in two parts, a circular wind and navigation calculator and a circular bombing angle calculator. Each part consists of a blacked metal disk with several circular sliding scales. On the navigation calculator the temperature (in degrees Celcius) and the rectified height (in feet) are set, the true height (in feet) is set, the barometric pressure is set, the rectified height is set (in thousands of feet) against the rectified airspeed and finally the true airspeed is read. On the bombing angle computer the height above target is set against groundspeed, and the bombing angle is read. This disc is marked Mark 1 Ref No 9/4482.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Analogue Computer, EAI 180, 1972
Analogue computer, EAI180, wood / metal / glass / cable / plastic, made by EAI (Electronics Associates Incorporated), Australia, 1972 This is a hybrid mechanical/electronic analogue computer. It was made in Australia by EAI Australia for the Australian market and for export. The EAI 180 is a low cost system for modelling a variety of communications systems. For this purpose it contains the necessary signal generators, signal processors and measuring equipment in both the time and the frequency domain. The EAI 180 can be expanded from a small system capable of solving a second order differential equation to having sufficient computing and logic power to solve an automatic optimisation and plotting of three differential equations. The equipment is housed in a cabinet, which has 5 panels: top panel has a column of plugholes for integrators and dual summers; there are 12 red overload indicator lights and an amplifier selector; a digit readout system is an integral part of the system, providing a reliable display of amplifier balance and output; functions are selected by four push buttons; panel 2 is as the top panel; panel 3 has rows of potentiometers (18) and a number of plugs for op-amps; panel 4 has 10 potentiometers for setting variables; panel 5 has a number of plugs for flip-flops and gates; at the bottom there is a drawer for jacks and other equipment. At the time, EAI Australia marketed very well in Europe, but the American mother company would not allow it to export to the USA. Professor Bromley stated that the Australian computer was better than the American models; it was very flexible, and was used for teaching, in medical laboratories, etc.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Waymouth-Cooke naval range finder. Mk.II, 1914 - 1919

Object Title: Naval range computer, 1935 - 1945

At the top there are two windows covered by clear plastic to view calculations - one large round window and one small rectangle with a three-numeral readout. On the left side there are two dials that feature the outline shape of a ship; these can be dialed to calculate relative direction and range of two naval vessels. One dial for enemy ships and one for own ships. The right side has two further dials for inputting calculations. There is another round clear plastic covered window in the centre of the array. Object Title: Alidade with Parallel Rule, 1930
Sight with case, elidade with parallel rule, artillery use. aluminium / wooden / leather, made by W Ottway and Co, London, England, 1930 Sight, Alidade with Parallel Rule for use with Field Plotting Board for artillery use. Blacked aluminium. In wooden case with leather flap and pocket. Mfr: W. Ottway & Co - Manufacturers - Ealing, London 1930 - No.A 938 - [D Broadarrow] An alidade is a device that allows a surveyor to sight an object some distance away (in the artillery this may be the target) and then draw a line on a plotting (or plane) table. It consists in a flat ruler with hinged vanes at each end that are raised to make a sighting. One of the vanes has a narrow slit for sighting through and the other has a wire hairline. It is aligned with the target while on the plotting table and supposing a map or other drawing has been aligned correctly, to North for example, then it will give the bearing of the target with respect to North. This alidade has a parallel rule attached.
Marks: W. Ottway & Co - Manufacturers - Ealing, London 1930 - No.A 938 - [D Broadarrow]
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Steward, Ltd., 406 Strand, London. from the 'Instructions for Use' sheet: "Set V.T.M. against the No. of Vehicles on the left hand of the slide; Time past a point is read against M.I.H. in the right hand of the Slide. In the window at the back, read at the Arrow-Heads the length of the column in miles and kilometres. When the number of vehicles exceeds 250, the correct result will be obtained dividing the number of vehicles by (say 10) before setting the Slide. The reading given on the Time Scale multiplied by (say 10), will then be the correct solution."

Object Title: US Army Air Force B24 load adjuster, 1945
Slide rule with case, US Army Air Force load adjuster, closed frame, single-sided, special purpose, plastic / Bakelite / leather, made by Cox and Stevens Aircraft Corp, Minoela, New York, United States of America, c. 1945 Slide rule, US Army Air Force load adjuster, closed frame, single-sided, special purpose, plastic laminate on Bakelite stock, with double-sided slide and panel on reverse illustrating interior plan of aircraft. In leather holster case labelled "Load Adjuster - Property of US Government". Cox and Stevens Aircraft Corp, Minoela, New York, USA, c. 1945 For use with US Army Airforce B24 Liberator bombers and US Navy PB24 anti-submarine reconnaissance aircraft. Scales: Various indicators of load (weight) for different compartments and the materials to be loaded therein. Each item to be stored on the aircraft, including fuel, bombs and crew, has a weight which adds to a shift in the balance of the aircraft (the centre of gravity) away from its centre line thus tending to cause it to turn towards the point of this mass. This is the turning "moment" of the load. The accumulation of various loads in different parts of the aircraft needs to be balanced out so that the aircraft's tendency to stray from its course is minimised. The scales are not logarithmic but simple linear scales because the rule's function is to add the moments as they are distributed over the aircraft. Bromley note: Not really a slide rule, but a means of adding moments for loadings in various aircraft compartments. (Serves the same purpose as "Librascope")
Marks: Face: Load Adjuster - Loading Range - B-24D,E,G,H, & J - PB24Y-1, plus scale labels for various locations in aircraft. Reverse: Diagram of interior plan of B24. There is a paper tag in a transparent slot on the reverse of the case marked AAF# 44-40443 [AAF is Army Air Force] Model B-24J Basic Wt 37 956 Index 66.6
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Addometer stylus operated adding machine, 1920 - 1960
Mechanical calculator with instructions and packaging, Addometer, stylus operated adding machine, metal / plastic / paper, made by the Reliable Typewriter & Adding Machine Corporation, United States of Amercia, 1920-1960 Calculator, Addometer Model C, mechanical, stylus operated adding machine, folded steel with eight rotating disk number dials each with carry mechanisms for addition (inner numbers) and subtraction (outer numbers), with instruction sheet and in original card box, metal / plastic / paper. This type of calculator follows the principle developed by Blaise Pascal for adding devices except that subtraction is easier since the dials can be turned in both directions. The dials have holes punched into them which rotate with a stylus (which remains with the calculator) thus acting as counters. Each counter (except the highest dial) has a carry mechanism which propagates the count into the next higher digit dial. The right most dial counts in 1/8ths of an inch and the next left dial counts to 12 for calculations involving measurements in feet and inches. There is a lever in the body of the calculator which when pulled resets all counting dials to zero. There is a ruler marked in inches and 1/16ths of an inch at the top edge. Instructions on the edge of the body of the calculator: (+) To Add - use large figures - Turn to right (-) To Subtract - use small figures - Turn to left
Marks: on face: Addometer on bottom edge: Patents Pending in USA and Foreign Countries Reliable Typewriter & Adding Machine Corporation - Made in USA

Measuring cards (2), Radius of the Curve of a rail line, cardboard, maker unknown, early 20th century Two cards having formula and procedure for measuring the Radius of the Curve of a rail line. 1: paper on card with handwritten formulae and instructions, 2: paper on light timber with handwritten formulae and instructions. unknown makers. Hand written rectangular cards with a diagram indicating the procedure and a scale of the radius (in chains) for different offsets of the 20ft chord to the curve of the rail. The offset is the difference in feet between the centre of the string indicating the chord and the centre of the rail curve marked by that chord. Thus (as can be seen on the top scan) for an offset of 2 1/8th inches the radius of the circle of which the rail curve is an arc is 4.28 chains (a chain is 22 yards or 20.1168m)

Wood, celluloid scale faces, in cloth covered card case with stencil printed instructions on Gallagher and Crompton letterhead, Manchester, UK, 1919 Crompton and Gallagher Boiler Efficiency Calculator. Crompton-Gallagher Patent No.128,878/1919 Scales: Stock, upper: (D) Calorific Value of Fuel, British Thermal Units (for low grade fuel, coal, Tar oil, Oils); Pounds of Water Evaporated per Lb. of Fuel Slide, upper stock: (Slide C) Factors of Evaporation, Efficiency %, Pounds of Water Evaporated  Stock, upper mid: (E) Lbs of Water Evaporated per Lb of Fuel Slide, lower: (Slide A) Temperature of Feed Water Stock, lower: (B) Factors of Evaporation. Corrected for Super Heat Transverse slide chart: Nomographs of Superheat Curves for Boiler Pressure and Temperature of Saturated Steam. Three values are needed to use the calculator; the observed Boiler Pressure, the observed Temperature of the Feed-water and the observed degree of superheat. The transverse chart is slid against the bevelled edge of the slide A until it stands at the line that represents the boiler pressure. Slide A is then slid across the chart until the observed feedwater temperature matches the point where the nomograph curve of the degree of superheat intersects the boiler pressure line. The gauge pointer of slide A will then point to the Evaporation Factor on scale B.

Object Title: Gilson A-B circular slide rule, 1940

In vinyl pouch with instruction booklets for each type (A and B). Gilson Slide Rule Co, Stuart Florida, 1940 The A-B slide rule is a double sided disk slide rule of white enamelled metal with a large central bolt that hold two pairs of cursors on either side. One side is called the "Atlas" Slide rule and the other is the "Binary" Slide Rule. It is housed in a leatherette sheath and comes with instruction booklets for both types. Included in an envelope (dated 1953) are leaflets for the two types of slide rules. The Binary Slide rule side has multiple scales from the standard set arrayed around the circle of 63cm circumference (at the outer edge) for greater precision. Scales are: from the outer ring: C, CI (C inverted), A, K, L, LL4, LL3, LL2, LL1, B, and then a set for machinists including scales in mm and 64ths of an inch. The Atlas Side Rule has three scales on it: the outer one is effectively 62cm (20 inches) long, the main one is a long spiral giving a precision equivalent to a straight scale 18.24 metres (60 feet) long, and the inner scale appears to be use for counting rotations around the long coil. Mfr: The Gilson Slide Rule Co, Stuart, Florida

Object Title: Pilot balloon slide rule, 1960 - 1980
Slide rule with case, Pilot Balloon Mark IV A, closed frame, plastic / wood / metal, laminate, made by Blundell Rules Ltd, England, 1960-1980 Slide rule, Pilot Balloon, closed frame, large, single-sided, plastic laminate, multiple metal edged plastic cursors, in wooden box with baize interior, wood / plastic / metal, BRL Ident. No. Met/480 Pilot Balloon Slide Rule Mk.IV A Scales: Stock, upper: Log scale, Cosine Scale, Sine Scale, Azimuth Slide: Graticule *, 3-cycle log scale. Stock, Lower: Elevation, Secant2 Scale, Tangent Scale A Pilot Balloon is a hydrogen or helium filled balloon used for Meteorological purposes. It will have a tail of a known length from which its distance can be determined by measuring its apparent length. It is released to ascend to the upper atmosphere where it is taken by the wind and its travel can be followed by tracking with a theodolite. In this way the elevation data can provide wind speeds and direction by calculation with the Pilot Balloon slide rule. The upper two cursors are used to determine the distance in the northerly and easterly directions with respect to the launch point and the height is determined with the lower cursors and the Elevation scale apparent length of the tail. Ref: Meteorological Office: Handbook of Meteorological Instruments, Part II, Instruments for Upper Air Observations. London: HMSO 1961
Marks: Pilot Balloon Slide Rule, Mark IV A - Ident. No. Met/480

Object Title: Allbrit Amsler-type polar Planimeter, 1947
Planimeter with case, polar, Amsler-type, steel / plastic / leatherette, made by Alllbrit, United Kingdom, 1947 This object is an Amsler-type polar Planimeter in a blue velvet lined leatherette case. A supporting arm is anchored to the work table with a short cylinder having a sharp point like a compass needle. It is linked to the tracing arm with a ball headed pin that forms an elbow hinge. The tracing arm has at one end a carriage consisting in a pair of supports that hold between them the accumulator wheel and vernier. This carriage may be positioned along the tracing arm for the scale of the curve being measured. The accumulator wheel is the moving part that touches the table. There is a metal tracing pointer at the other end of the tracing arm. As the pointer is moved around the perimeter of the curve whose area is being measured the steel rim of the accumulator wheel rolls forwards or backwards and skids sideways. The scale is on the wheel itself, and indicates how far the wheel has turned. The final dial reading represents the sum of all the rim's rolling motions. This number is proportional to the area of the region.
Marks: The accumulator wheel and vernier carriage has the instrument number: 37324. The tracing arm has a scale marked from 5 to 16 in fine gradations of ten marks between each numbered scale. The case has a calibration chart glued in to the lid.

Object Title: Collection of photographic exposure calculators, 1900 - 1950
Calculators (8), photographic exposure, paper / plastic / leather, various makers, England / Germany, 1900-1950 P.159/504 #1 Ensign Posometer Slide chart, circular, exposure calculator, three concentric disks with inner disk rotatable against outer pair which are strapped together. Inner disk has notches for movement. In leather case. Celluloid / metal / leather. England, c.1930. Obverse has label and curved window for viewing exposure time settings against aperture settings for different times of day and different seasons. Reverse has table of plate speeds and their use for different subject (light) conditions. P.159/504 #2 Johnson Standard Exposure Calculator for negative film and plate in Daylight P.159/504 #3 Johnson Standard Exposure Calculator for colour & cine reversal films. Sliding charts, circular in square frames. The outer frame is a square envelope with faces either side and held together with a strap at the top edge. The inner disk has a scale of shutter speeds, with notches to aid rotation. Plastic / metal, England, c.1957. The obverse, label side has a window for reading shutter speed against lens aperture and a table of subject conditions. The reverse has a table of light values for times of the day and year, with weather conditions. P.159/504 #4 P.159/504 #5 P.159/504 #6 3 versions of the Imperial Exposure Meter Slide rule, booklet, Imperial Exposure Meter with Actinometer photographic paper light measuring tool. Card cover, card slide rule, instructions and actinometer. Paper / card / celluloid, England, post 1901. The three versions consist of an early version with instructions, a No.1 type for Bright light and a No.2 type for Dull light. An actinometer is used to measure the intensity of light in this case by counting the time it takes photographic print paper to reach the same colour as some standard indicated by the surround of the hole through which the paper is exposed. P.159/504 #7 Wellcome Photographic Exposure Calculator, Handbook and Diary, 1922 Slide chart, circular, contained in cloth bound card covered booklet consisting of a notebook and a diary, with frontispiece photographs and a folding package for storing small prints. Paper / metal / cloth. Burroughs Wellcome & Co. England, 1922. This booklet with calculator included would have been used by the photographer as a day-to-day notebook of details of photographs, exposure data etc for subsequent referral when setting up exposures for photographs. It also contains instructions for exposure and the use of the calculator dial plus advertisements for the Tabloid series of darkroom chemicals manufactured by Wellcome. P.159/504 #8 Loga Exposure meter / calculator Slide rule, linear, plastic laminate on black plastic support, holes along the centre of the support and the slide, celluloid sliding indicator. Loga, Germany. The holes have neutral density filter of differing grades in them. The scene is examined through these holes so that the density grade that shows the subject is set against lighting conditions, lens aperture or shutter speeds to determine appropriate exposure setting.

Object Title: Pitkin Chronograph No 324, 1900 - 1925
Calculating rule, Chronograph No 324, metal, made by James Pitkin and Co Ltd, London, England, early 20th century Mfr: James Pitkin & Co. Ltd, Makers, London Chronograph No.324 The Pitkin chronograph is a tool for calculating the muzzle velocity of a projectile when determining the ballistic characteristics of a gun. It consists of a long, narrow metal rule. At one end is a pivot point or rotating joint that allows the rule to turn through a full circle or to swing upwards from the horizontal. It has a double cursor-like rider one half of which has a vernier scale fixable with a knurled knob and having a knife edge set at right angles to the rule. The knife edge can be replaced by undoing a pair of screws and can be very precisely positioned. The other half of the cursor rider consists of a block of metal which can be set at a fixed distance from the vernier rider by a worm screw and also has a knurled knob to lock its position Scales: Edge, upper: Heights (in inches: 0 - 21.5) Edge, lower: Velocities - Feet per Second Gauge mark: Disjunction Screen Distance 120 feet This device is used in association with a Boulenge chronograph, in which two screens are placed in front of the gun one at the muzzle and one 120 feet away. In a Boulenge chronograph a rod is released by the breaking of an electric wire (the 'screen') placed at the muzzle and on the breaking of the second screen, 120 feet from the first, the drop of a second rod starts. The first rod has a knife on it which marks the second rod when the knife falls onto it. The time that elapses between the breaking of the two screens by the projectile is measured by the fall of the rod and the velocity of the projectile can be calculated from the duration of this interval, given that the distance of travel is known to be the distance between the two screens or 120 feet.
Marks: James Pitkin & Co. Ltd, Makers, London Chronograph No.324
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: The Magnameta oil tonnage calculator, 1960 - 1969
Slide rule with instructions and case, International Petoleum Tonnage Calculator, special construction, single-sided, paper / wood / plastic / metal, made by the Magnameta Company, Kent, England, 1960s Slide rule, special construction, single-sided, printed scales. The Magnameta oil tonnage calculator with instructions in wooden case, paper, wood, plastic, metal. Manufacturer: The Magnameta Co, Oasthouse Way, St Mary Cray, Kent, UK. Two pairs of long strips of light timber laminated to similar strips of slightly lesser width then laminated to a full length and width plastic (Perspex) panel for support. There are two more long strips of timber laminated underneath that function as supports for the whole. The slide is a single piece of timber that runs between the two long strips and is held by the undercut of the inner layer of timber on the side pieces. It is shorter than the main body of the rule. The slide has a slot cut into it through which a clamping wing nut locks the position of the large, chromed metal (nickel?) bounded, clear acetate cursor. The scales are printed on paper which is bonded to the top surfaces of the wooden panels of the rule. Scales: Upper stock: A: Barrels as One Tenth Scale Reading - in units of 'Cubic Feet in Thousands' and 'Tons As One Hundredth Scale Reading' Slide, upper: B: Specific gravity of the petroleum Slide, middle: C: ditto Slide, lower: D: API (American Petroleum Institute) gravity values Lower Stock: E: Ten times Scale Reading - Tons in Hundreds This slide rule was used for calculations required in the loading of oil tankers. The slide rule is large to allow greater precision. It is intended for use during the actual tanker loading process and is said to be "accurate enough to load the ship by" [Instruction booklet]. The cursor may be locked in position at a set gravity value of the oil being loaded, so that with a known specific gravity, say 900, a tank of 25,000 cubic feet will weigh 625 long, 635 metric or 700 short tons, (when using the appropriate gauge markers on the slide). The E scale may also be used to find the weight in American barrels. The slide rule was invented by C.J. Sangwin and patented in 1963. British Patent GB919063. Ref: http://web.mat.bham.ac.uk/C.J.Sangwin/Sliderules/specialsliderules.html
Marks: International Petroleum Tonnage Calculator - Registered Trade Mark - Magnameta - British Patent No.919063. in circular logo
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Spirule slide rule, 1960 - 1969
Circular slide rule with instruction sheet and packaging, Spirule, plastic / metal / paper, made by The Spirule Company, United States of America, 1960s Slide rule, circular, Spirule, plastic, metal. In original envelope with instructions sheet. Spirule Mfr'd: The Spirule Company, 9728 El Venado, Whittier, California 90603. U.S.A. © North American Aviation, Inc. Rotating ruler jointed to a circular disk via a centred rivet. The rotating ruler consists in a wide plastic rectangular element having curves marked on it and a ruler on one edge. It is a device for making practical calculations to approximate the parameters for a useful engineering feedback control system by a graphical analysis of its characteristic equation. It gives an indication of the natural behaviour of a closed loop control system by graphical means using what was known as the Root-Locus Method. It is used for summing the angles of vectors for the graphic determination of the product of a set of vectors.
Marks: on envelope: The Spirule Company, 9728 El Venado, Whittier, California 90603. U.S.A. on object: The Spirule Company, 9728 El Venado, Whittier, California 90603. U.S.A. © North American Aviation, Inc.

GE Mobile Radio Range and Signal Strength Calculator, ECR-16E Mfr'd by Graphic Calculator Company, Barrington, Illinois for General Electric Co, Mobile Radio Department, Lynchburg, Virginia [© 1952, this one may have been produced 4/72] Scales: starting side: Wrapper: Transmitting antenna height, Slide: Receiving antenna height, Key Number Wrapper: sum of Antenna gains, Table of correction factors for Transmitter Power and Transmission line losses. back side: Slide: Carrier frequency in Megahertz, Signal in Microvolts Wrapper: Key Number Transmitting antenna height is set against receiving antenna height and the Key Number (essentially a reference number for use in turning the calculator over) is read against the correction factor. Object Title: Cox's Stadia Computer, 1960 - 1969
Circular slide chart, Cox's Stadia Computer, single-sided, celluloid, made by W & L E Gurley, New York, United States of America, 1960-1970 Slide chart, circular, Cox's Stadia Computer, single-sided, concentric disk on square backing plate, white celluloid, survey functions, promotional. Gurley, Troy, N.Y., USA makers of surveyor's instruments original copyright: 1899, but obviously kept on being produced. Scales: scale on backing plate: circular logarithmic scale of the values, as read off the stadia rod, of the hairlines. inner disk scale: Scale of elevation angle of telescope, in degrees, for determining Difference of Elevation from logarithmic scale on backing plate (½ sin 2A), Hor. Distance (cos2 A) scale To use the "computer": Set the zero gauge point on the "Difference of Elevation" scale of the disk against the value at the central hairline as read off the stadia rod. Given that the difference value between the upper and lower hairlines is a constant at the telescope its difference value as read off the stadia rod will depend on the angle of elevation of the telescope and the distance to the stadia rod. The value of the horizontal distance to the stadia rod can then be read against the elevation angle at the section of the scales on the disk marked "Hor. Distance".

Stock, lower: A running 4 - 40, an extension of A on upper stock, Reverse: Stock, upper: C running 30 - 300 inverted, an extension of the C scale from the lower stock. Object Title: System Cuntz slide rule calculator by Schacht & Westerich, 1914 - 1920
Slide rule, System Cuntz, closed frame, celluloid / wood / metal / glass, made by Schacht & Westerich, Hamburg, Germany, 1914-1920 Slide rule, System Cuntz, closed frame, celluloid laminate on wood, multiple scales on upper stock, narrow slide having only one (Q+1) scale. Metal-rimmed glass cursor (cracked). "System Cuntz" - Slide Rule Calculator - Schacht & Westerich Slide Rule US Patent granted, Jan 11, 1916 - No.1,168,059 There is also British patent for 1914 - GB 191325947 Mfr: Schacht & Westerich, Hamburg, Germany Scales: Stock upper: L, t, s, st, d2(pi)/4, n(pi), three cube root scales, two square root scales. Slide: Q+1 Stock lower: n2, 1:n The scales are arranged in groups according to their function. The basic scale of numbers (on most slide rules called the D scale) is here represented by the label n23 and its reciprocal (usually DI) is marked 1:n. Each consist in a single cycle running 1 - 10. The slide has a single scale, here labelled Q+1 (and usually labelled C). Above the slide are 5 groups of scales, the first being a pair of scales for the square roots of the units (U), the hundreds (H) and the tens of Thousands (Ttheta) and for the square roots of the tens (T), the thousands (theta) and the hundreds of thousands (Htheta). Above this are three scales for cube roots being organised in a similar way as the square roots in Units (U), thousands (theta), millions (M); tens (T), tens of thousands (Ttheta); and then hundreds (H) and hundreds of thousands (Htheta). Above this scale are two scales marked n(pi) used for the circumference of a circle and d^2(pi)/4 used for calculating the area of a circle. Above this are three trigonometric scales: 0.01st which is for the sine or tangent of small angles and then 0.1s and 0.1t which are fro the sine or tangent of larger angles, respectively. Above this is a scale marked L which is a line of equal parts
Marks: numerous scale labels, Schacht & Westerich Slide Rule, "System Cuntz", Patent Appl
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Jackson Bros of Armley were manufacturers of drawing instruments Mannheim's scales were the "C" and "D" scales that reflect the scales originally drawn on Gunter's Line, ranging from 1 (the index) to 10 and the "A" and "B" scales which range from 1 (the index) to 100. The "C" and "D" scales are the basic scales used for multiplication and division and the "A" and "B" scales are used for squares and square roots, such that if the index points on the "A" and the "D" scales are aligned the value read on the "A" scale is the square of the number on the "D" scale.
Marks: on reverse: Jackson Brothers Limited Armley Leeds

The "C" and "D" scales are the basic scales used for multiplication and division and the "A" and "B" scales are used for squares and square roots, such that if the index points on the "A" and the "D" scales are aligned the value read on the "A" scale is the square of the number on the "D" scale.

Object Title: Gravet Lenoir Soho type slide rule, 1870 - 1892
Slide rule, Soho type, closed frame, single sided, double-sided slide, laminated wood, made by Gravet Lenoir, Paris, France, 1870-1882 The rule is marked with both the names Gravet Lenoir and Tavernier & Vinay and the address given is 39 rue de Babylone, Paris, which Tavernier & Vinay occupied between 1870 and 1882. This suggests that the rule was designed by Gravet Lenoir somewhat earlier in the 19th century, but handed on to Tavernier & Vinay when they took over the company. It is based on the Boulton and Watt 'Soho' design. Scales: "Soho" arrangement Stock, upper: A (2 cycles of 1 - 10), Slide, obverse: B, C, (as A) Slide, reverse: S, T, line of equal parts (running inverted 0 - 1000) Stock, lower: D (one cycle of 1 - 10)

Object Title: Dring & Fage spirits reducing slide rule
Slide rule, Proof reduction, duplex, open frame, brass / boxwood, made by Dring & Fage, London, England, after 1896 Dring and Fage proof reducing rule. This is a slide rule to calculate the amount of water to add to a spirit liquor to reduce its proof to some desired level. It is a rule consisting in three strips of wood bound together at each end by brass bands that are riveted together through the stock pieces. The slide is held in the stock by a tongue and groove arrangement on either side. No cursor. Scales: Two A scales of logarithmic proportion - on the upper stock, obverse, running from 1 to 10 and on the lower stock, with an overlap, running from 4 to 40. On the reverse are two C scales of logarithmic proportion, one running from 10 to 100 and the other from 60 to 300. The slide is identical on each side and indicates the proof values, running from 80 UP to 70 OP. Mfr: Dring & Fage, 145 Strand, London
Marks: Dring & Fage Makers 145 Strand London Trade Mark Patent No. 14623

Object Title: Cooke, Troughton and Simms pipes and sewers discharge calculator, 1920 - 1930
Slide rule, Cooke Troughton and Simms, hydraulic, closed frame, single-sided, special purpose, double-sided slide, wood, made by Cooke, Troughton and Simms Ltd, London, England, c. 1925 Pipes and sewers discharge calculator. Scales: Stock upper: 10 - 10,000 log scale Slide, obverse: Circular Pipes full velocity, (in Feet per Min); Discharges, (in Cubic Feet per Min); Gradient values (eg. 1 in 400); Egg Shaped Sewers full velocity, feet per min; Discharges cubic feet per min; using the Kutter formula Slide, reverse: as obverse but differently apportioned for use with the Grimp and Bruges formula. Stock lower: R indicator for gradient, then (running 100 - 10,000) as upper stock. To use: Set the R indicator (on the lower stock) to the gradient value. Read Velocity (in feet per minute) from the pipe diameter scale (say 36") and read the discharge rate (in cubic feet per minute) from the circled diameter value (say 36). For example: With R set to a gradient of 1 in 100 the pipe, of diameter 36inches and being full, the flow velocity will be 565 feet per minute and the discharge rate will be 400 cubic feet per minute. Mfr: Cooke, Troughton and Simms, Ltd. London & York, post 1922.
Marks: on face: various scales and scale labels on reverse: Cooke, Troughton and Simms, Ltd. London & York

Object Title: Alcohol Proofing slide rule by T Gill of London, 1775 - 1799
Slide rule, alcohol proofing, ivory / electrum, made by T Gill, London, England, late 1700s Ivory Gauging rule by T. Gill of London The stock is a single sheet of ivory. The slides are a pair of slivers of ivory secured by two screws that pass through a central slot in the stock. Both the slides and the stock are engraved with scales for alcohol proof calculations. Scales: At the top left of either side there is a scale on the slide which is to be set against a fleur-de-lys index marker on the stock. This is the adjustment for the temperature of the liquor. The rest of the stock is occupied by a series of increasing ranges of a scale of Proof. The 1st scale runs from a Water gauge point of 100 (no alcohol in the solution) to 80. The 2nd scale ranges from 80 down to a star gauge index at 16 (at which point the liquor was considered seizable for being too much underproof, ie, below an adequate alcohol content) and then to a Proof gauge point of 0 and on to an overproof level of 10. The 3rd scale (now on the opposite side of the rule) ranges from 20 underproof to 28 overproof through a Proof index point at 0. The 4th scale ranges from 20 overproof to 67 overproof with a Proof index of 66.5. The two scales on this side are of much greater precision than those on the first side. The hydrometer weight values read from the liquor using the hydrometer are applied to the slides on each side in four increasing ranges. On the 1st side the 1st hydrometer scale runs from 0 - 13, the 2nd runs from 11 - 80. On the 2nd side the 3rd scale runs from 30 - 100 and the 4th scale runs from 93 - 180. The scales on the outer edge show the strengths of alcohol as measured by another type of hydrometer known as Clark's hydrometer. The gauge point SW marks the strength of a very good Spirits of Wine.
Marks: T.Gill. London. various gauge marks including Fleur-de-lys symbol, plus gauge labels: Proof, Alcohol, Water
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Dring & Fage proofing and excise slide rule
Slide rule, proofing and excise, duplex, brass / wood / ivory, made by Dring & Fage, London, England, 19th century Slide rule, Dring & Fage, proofing and excise, duplex, brass straps, wood with ivory slide. Scales: all four faces of the stock have an increasing range of values in scales labelled CON, IM, EX. the slide has a series of numbers running from 1 - 36 and grouped as A, 29 - 73 and grouped as B and C on one side, with numbers running from 68 - 93 and grouped as D and finally from 92 - 100 which group is not labelled. It is possible that the function of the rule is as a conversion device for converting import tariffs or export tariffs according to the Proof (alcohol content) of the liquor concerned. There are proof gauge points in each of the IM and EX scales. There is also a scale which has what is probably a gauge point marked Water at 100 units which then decrements to a gauge point marked PR at 0 units and then increments again to 80 units (the units may be Percent). At the end of the scales there is a marked off section which has an index point on the slide and what are probably correction factors for temperature for the IM and EX scales
Marks: Dring & Fage Makers 20 Tooley St London Bridge

Object Title: Dring & Fage slide rule for use with a saccharometer, 1825 - 1835
Slide rule, saccharometer, duplex, open frame, brass / wood / ivory, made by Dring & Fage, London, England, c. 1830 This is a slide rule that would normally accompany a hydrometer. It is a boxwood rule consisting in two strips of wood held together at each end by brass bands that are riveted together through the stocks. The slide is of bone and is approximately one third the length of the stocks. It has identical A and B scales on the obverse and identical D and E scales on the reverse. It is held in the stock by a tongue and groove arrangement on either side. No cursor. 34cm overall, 32cm scales Scales: The scales on this slide rule are engraved in four sets repeated over the two pairs (upper and lower) of sides (obverse and reverse) of the stock. Each repeat has a range of values with some overlap that give the rule a precision greater than what would be available if the full range were engraved over one section only. There are scales labelled Specific Gravity: the absolute weight of a cubic foot of some material, where water has a specific gravity of nearly 1000 ounces, measured at 60°F. Proof Spt pr ct, Percentage of proof spirit D. Ex. pr Bar'l, D. Ex. Pr. Cent, Density. For Specific Gravity: Obverse: Stock lower: running 0 - 54 Obverse: Stock upper: running 31 - 87 Reverse: Stock lower: running 65 - 125 Reverse: Stock upper: running 100 - 164 The slide and its immediately adjacent scales on the stock will function as a basic slide rule, with A and B scales on the obverse and C and D scales on the reverse. Mfr: Dring & Fage, 20 Tooley St, London, c. 1830 (Hopp, p.66)
Marks: Dring & Fage, No. 20 Tooley St, London.

Object Title: Gauging rule by George Mander, 1840 - 1875
Slide rule with case, gauging, duplex, open frame, dual slide, ivory / metal / leather, made by George Mander, London, England, c. 1845-1870 This is an excise or gauging slide rule. It is a double-slide, duplex, bone rule by George Mander of 25 Old Compton St, London. The stock consists in three strips of ivory held together at each end by electrum bands which are riveted together through the stock pieces. The two slides are set between the stock pieces and are held in place by strips of wood, mounted into the stocks as a tongue and groove arrangement. There is no cursor. The rule comes in a leather pouch. Scales: Edge, upper: 9 inch ruler Variety lines for calculating volume of cask: Spheroid, 2nd Variety Obverse: Stock, upper: A (1 cycle) Slide, upper: B (as A) with gauge point G (Imperial Gallon at 2.77) Stock, middle: SEGT LY (segment lying) 2nd Variety 1st Variety A (as A on upper stock) with gauge points B (Imperial Bushel at 2.21), G (Imperial Gallon 2.77) Slide, lower: C (as A) Stock, lower: MD (Malt Depth, 1 cycle, folded at 2.15) Edge, lower Unlabeled scale same as A Unlabeled scale as A but folded at 1.625 Reverse Stock, upper: Single, high resolution scale running 1 - 3.2 with gauge point G at 1.878 Slide, upper: B (as A) Stock, middle: D extension of high resolution scale on upper stock running 3.2 -10, with gauge points MS (malt square at 4.73) "for malt square, is at 46.3, the square root of 2150.42, or the side of a square whose content is equal to the number of inches in a solid bushel MR (malt round at 5.32) for malt-round, is at 52.32, the diameter of a cylinder, or bushel, the area of whose base is the same 2150.42, the inches in a bushel.": [Hutton] HS Variety (running 19 - 23.4, equal parts, partial length of rule, possibly Hyperbolic Spindle) YS Variety (running 19 - 22.7, equal parts, partial length of rule) A Slide, lower: C (as A) Stock, lower: SEGT ST (segment standing) in two parts: the lower line running 1 - 8, and the upper line running 8 - 100 Upper and lower slides have an electrum endplate, riveted to the slide on its face, to allow the two slides to be set into a single channel for extra precision. 25cm
Marks: G. Mander. Maker. 25 Old Compton St. Soho. London

Object Title: Everard gauging slide rule, 1700 - 1725
Slide rule, Everard, gauging, wood / metal, maker unknown, early 1700s Slide rule, Everard, gauging, rectangular section with two slides on opposite faces, edge faces also have scales, wood, metal eyelet in one end. Scales: Side 1 stock: A (2 cycles), with gauge points MB (Malt Bushel at 2.15), and A (Ale gallon of 282 cubic inches). Side 1, slide: B (as A0), with gauge points Si (square inscribed = 0.707, being the side of a square inscribed in a circle), Se (square equal = 0.886, being the side of a square of equal area to a unit circle), W (wine gallon of 231 cubic inches) and C (circumference, or pi at 3.14). Side 1 stock: MD (Malt Depth, 2 cycles, folded at 2.15) Side 2: 18 inch rule, three Variety Lines - Spheroid, 2nd Variety, 3rd Variety. Side 3: D, (single cycle, 1 - 10), with gauge points WG (wine gauge at 17.15), AG (ale gauge at 18.95), MS (malt square = 46.37) and MR (malt round = 52.32). Side 3, slide: C (as A), with gauge points od (the area of a circle with circumference of 1 = 0.0796), oc (the area of a circle with diameter of 1 = 0.7854) Side 3: Seg S (segment standing), Seg L (segment lying) Side 4: FM, IM (divided in inches and tenths of an inch), FC (Frustum of two cones) [The descriptions of the gauge points are due to Hopp, p.289] This version is longer than the first versions made by Everard, which were exactly a foot (30cm) long. This rule is 47 cm x 2.9 cm x 1.5 cm
Marks: logo: TC with fleur-de-lys stamped into channel of slide on side 3.

Object Title: Coggeshall type jointed carpenters' slide rule by John Rabone and Sons, 1845 - 1855

Object Title: Gunter's Rule, short version, 1785 - 1795
Calculating rule, Gunter's liine, double-sided, boxwood, maker unknown, c. 1790 Gunter's rule, double-sided, boxwood. Obverse has the diagonal scale. Reverse has a number of hand-stamped scales. It is possibly quite early since it has a limited number of scales: TR, NUM, SIN, VS, TAN, MER, EP. It is unsigned. Bromley suggests c.1790. 30.5 cm x 2.8 cm x 0.4 cm The Gunter's Rule was the precursor to the slide rule as it has no slide. Values in the scales are placed as the logarithm of the number. Arithmetic functions were performed by opening a divider to the width of the first number and then reading off the value of the result by placing one leg of the open divider at the second number, the extended leg of the divider then points to the result value. The slide rule developed by placing a pair of Gunter's rules together and reading the result by placing a hairline across the pair of rules.
Marks: scale values and mnemonics.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Kane Mk-6B dead reckoning computer, 1958
Kane Mk-6B dead reckoning computer with pouch, instruction booklet, warranty card and packaging, metal / plastic / paper / cardboard, made by the Kane Aero Company, United States of America, 1958 Kane Mk-6B - Dead Reckoning Computer is a Dead Reckoning calculator used in aerial navigation. It consists in a flat metal (aluminium) plate, having a radial chart printed on it in green, which is inserted into a circular slide rule like device.There is a circular insert with a compass bearing scale around the circumference having a plastic chart on which the track of flight is marked (in pencil). The whole is housed in a shaped, grey vinyl pouch when not in use and is accompanied by an instruction booklet, warranty card and original packaging. Navigation is now achieved mostly by electronic means, beginning with wireless navigation and nowdays with GPS.
Marks: Numerous markings indicating use, scales, compass points and bearings, and calculating details such as inputs. Brand marking is "Kane Aero Co", St Paul, Minn.

Object Title: Cuisenaire teacher's pack, 1965 - 1980
Cuisenaire rods with booklet and box, wood / metal / paper, made by the Cuisenaire Company, Australia, 1965-1980 This object consists of a sheet metal box, containing 10 compartments, each with a single size of wooden blocks in different colours. Object Title: Plessey core memory, 1955 - 1965
Computer memory, ferrite core memory block (possibly for KDF9 computer), metal / plastic / Bakelite, made by Plessey Co Ltd, England, c. 1960 Plessey core memory block. metal box approx 19inches long by 4 inches square in a blue enamel finish. One face has 8 Centronics connectors arrayed on it in pairs. There is a label block in the middke of this face. It has not been opened but should contain a set of core memory frames similar to those covered in P.159/94. This memory block is said to have been part of the KDF9 at the Basser Department of Computer Science at the University of Sydney. The KDF9 was one of the first computers to have a full pre-emptive operating system. The computer had up to 32 kilobytes of memory - there were no discs, backing storage was provided by magnetic tape units that could be partially rewound and overwritten. The software system known as the Director was sophisticated for its time, because it provided fully pre-emptive process switching.
Marks: Plessey logo
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Baby Brunsviga calculator, 1910 - 1920
Mechanical pinwheel calculator, Baby Brunsviga, wood / metal, made by Talis and Company, Braunschweig, Germany, 1910-1920 This is a manual, mechanical calculator of pin-wheel variety. In Germany this type is often called the Odhner machine, because Odhner was the first in Europe to use the pinwheel mechanism in calculating machines. This model is a Brunsviga Serial No. 22684, known as a 'Baby Brunsviga' model. The serial number indicates that it was made between 1910 and 1920. It is well used. It is mounted on a timber plate with locked cases.

Object Title: Ferrite core memory, 1970 - 1979
Computer memory block, metal / plastic / ferrite cores / insulated wiring, maker unknown, 1970s This is a large block of ferrite core memory in a 19inch rack mounting frame. The cores are threaded on fine wires in pairs of rectangular units held by metal frames with connecting pins on the outside of each frame to which bundles of insulated wires are soldered. The insulated wires are then loomed and distributed to interconnection sockets on the outer edges of the rack frame. It is not known what computer this memory was used in, although initial suggestions have been that it was the KDF9 at the University of Sydney, but this seems unlikely given that this block appears to have been made in the 1970s.
Marks: RCA
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Four transistor circuit boards, 1966 - 1975
Printed circuit boards (4), transistor, metal / fibreglass / plastic, Control Data Corporation, United States of America, 1966-1975 Four similar transistor circuit boards made by Control Data Corporation. They are logic units using silicon transistors and built with the "cordwood" technique, in which the components, using axial connecting leads, are connected into the facing pair of printed circuit boards. These particular objects are probably from a CDC1700. One of which was in the network at the University of Sydney Basser Department of Computer Science. The front of the boards are marked: ZT - ZT - ZO3 - VO2, and the back of the boards are marked: BYKTT - BYAKTT - AYHTT- 1794540IBYITT.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: HP logic state analyser 1602A, 1970 - 1979
HP logic state analyser 1602A, plastic, made by Hewlett Packard, United States of America, 1970s This is a complex piece of test equipment. It is used to test and debug digital systems, in particular new systems. It has 18 channels and a multi-channel probe. It is used both for timing and for logic state analysis. It has a keyboard, and there is a LED alpha-numeric light panel, divided into three sections. It is housed in a beige plastic case, the back section is a storage chamber for the probe unit, which is connected to the main unit by a 40-channel ribbon; probe has 18 clips attached to IC legs; keyboard below the LED display. Instructions under the lid. There is a light panel, divided into 3 sections.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: National accounting machine, 1935 - 1945
Accounting machine, metal / plastic, made by the National Cash Register Company, United States of America, c. 1940 The National accounting machine, like the Burroughs adding machine, was used for adding and ledger posting. The National has an alpha keyboard to enable labelling of columns, etc, as well as the numeric keyboard.

Object Title: Aerotopograph plotting instrument, 1950 - 1959
Stereoscope with case and manual, aerotopograph plotting instrument for compiling maps, metal / glass / plastic / wood, made by Zeiss Aerotopograph, Germany, 1950-1960 This aerotopograph, or stereotopograph, is a stereoscopic plotting instrument used for the compilation of topographic maps from aerial photographs, the axis of which are vertical, or nearly so. It has a Wheatstone stereo viewer for photogrammetry, lenses and a lens-holder and frame and mirrors. There is a lighting lamp and a series of magnets for holding down photos. The main element of the instrument is the stereoscope with obliquely positioned monocular eyepieces. By means of a hinged adapter these can be swung into position for rapid change from overall to detail coverage. The instrument is easily transportable in its carry cases - one box contains the base plate, mirrors, holders, monoculars and filters, the other contains the base plate, picture carriage built-in computers, pantograph and accessories. The aerotopograph allows the plotting of pictures in their original size. The object comes with Stereoscopic instruction manual and 50 aerial stereo photo prints.
Marks: The portable carry cases are marked with the number 38.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Logic mini trainer No.3
Logic Mini Trainer, (3 units), metal / plasticmade by the Basser Department of Computer Science, University of Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, c. 1971 The Mini Logic Trainer was developed in the Basser Department of Computer Science originally by Arthur Sale with later developments by Allan Bromley. There are 3 copies of the Logic MiniTrainer here. Nos.3 and 4 are identical single rack panel versions, while No.1 is a dual panel version made up of a pair of the same panels as on the single panel versions. The panels are mounted in blue hammer finish metal 19-inch rack frames with, in Nos.3 and 4, the actual logic panel mounted at a sloped angle to aid access. Each panel consists in a set of TTL or CMOS logic modules implemented as printed circuit boards having connector sockets, switches, LEDs and a clock speed potentiometer on them. Each board also has a logic diagram of the implemented circuit screen printed onto its surface. Logic circuits are made up by connecting patch leads between modules. There is a cardboard box of spare patch leads with the set.
Marks: BDCS logo | Basser Logic MiniTrainer No. 1 BDCS logo | Basser Logic MiniTrainer No. 3 BDCS logo | Basser Logic MiniTrainer No. 4
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Experimental clock, 1970 - 1980
Unknown device, possibly experimental clock, metal / plastic / insulation, possibly student's work, Australia, 1970-1980 This device has electronic, electrical and mechanical features. It is mounted in a blue hammer-tone metal 19" rack mounted front panel, bolted to a pair of right-angle steel supports. Mounted on this panel are a number of inter-connected discs with scales in degrees. Stepper motors are connected to the discs via gears. There are two servo motors and six electric resolvers from Vernitron Corporation. Circuits may be re-patched via patchcords. At the back of the device there are circuit boards for the controller. It may be a home-made student project, and is probaly associated with the O'Leary Clock.

Object Title: Naval rangefinder converter, 1925 - 1954
Rangefinder converter, wood / metal / plastic, maker unknown, c. 1930-1949 For maritime navigation calculations. Scales mounted on heavy plywood base. Object Title: Two rangefinder converters, 1942
Rangefinder converters (2), metal / masonite, made by E E & S, England, 1942 A flat rectangular board bounded by a metal edge and having a pair of parallel metal indicators. The board has a semi-circular polar grid laid out on it. It is a graphical device for plotting the position of an aircraft on a map given its bearing (the direction to it from the point of view of an observer), its angle above the horizon and the distance to the aircraft along this slant. It solves the vertical triangle giving the height of the aircraft and its position on the map for anti-aircraft artillery range-finder calculations. In use it converts polar to linear co-ordinates. A sliding linear scale is graduated 1 - 40, i.e. 1,000 - 40,000 feet; and a logarithmic circular scale shows the radius to 19,000 feet, i.e., marked each 10 degrees from 0 to 5,000 feet, each 5 degrees from 5,000 to 10,000 feet, and each degree from 10,000 feet to 19,000 feet.
Marks: Marked EE and S 1942, D and D No. 311 (one of models), 314 (other model).
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Coincidence optical range finder, 1925 - 1945
Rangefinder, Optical Coincidence, metal / glass, made by Adam Hilger Ltd, England, c. 1930-1940 This technology was developed for artillery purposes, where the range to the enemy is vital. This type of rangefinder was easy to use and fairly accurate. It consists of a long cylinder made from black metal. It has an objective lense with rotating cover each end, an eyepiece at the centre and thumbwheel adjustment. Two telescopes are located in the tube, separated by a known distance. With the target object located and the range needed, the range finder is adjusted so the two fields of view from the two telescopes are given in a single field of view. One is inverted in a central window. The views may be observed through the eyepiece. The two views are brought into coincidence horizontally by adjusting a roller geared to a distance scale.
Marks: The instrument is marked with the manufacturer's name, Adam Hilger. A label is marked Marindin Infantry No.1, Mark 35.37 (?).
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Astrograph, Type A-1, 1935 - 1945
Astrograph with box, Type A-1, metal / glass, made by the Sperti Company, Cincinatti, United States of America, used by the US Army, c. 1940 It has lighting components behind a window. On the front there is a polar scale with Longitude and Latitude, which may be scrolled. The instrument is packed in a cast metal box with screwed-on shelf with the main components. In the bottom there are compartments for parts. The Astrograph was made by the Sperti Company in Cincinatti, USA.

Object Title: Bearing corrector, 1900 - 1925

Object Title: Totalisator accumulator, 1962
Totalisator accumulator, metal / brass / cotton, maker unknown, England, 1962 This mechanical accumulator consists of a cast brass base, on which are mounted six 110 Volt DC relays, each with two coils. From the frame is suspended a shaft adder, which has five different gears and six sprockets, representing different multiples of the unit price (50 pence), i.e., 50 p, 1 pound, 2 pounds, etc. The differentials act as adders of the value of the ticket, and the ticket machine sends a signal, which through the relays releases the cog relating to the value of the ticket. There were no springs; if power should be lost, tickets paid would be honoured. The accumulator was used for Win and Place betting. This unit comes from the Julius Totalisator in Wembley, UK.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Vickers No.1 anti-aircraft predictor, 1942
Analogue computer, Anti-Aircraft Predictor, Vickers No.1 Mk III, metal / glass, designed by Vickers Limited, England, 1924, made by Sperry Gyroscope, United States of America, 1942 This instrument is an analogue computer. It is mechanical and works in real-time, forming part of a World War II anti-aircraft unit for spotting and tracking enemy aircraft and for controlling anti-aircraft fire. There are two separate metal cases. The main section has the other section bolted on top. A number of glass windows reveal dials, cylindrical charts, various knobs for making adjustments. The top case is empty. There is a 360 degrees disc under the box for positioning on the gun. There are two separate parts of telescopic sights: bearing and elevation. Works to 30,000 feet; at this height the shell takes 30 secs. Initially designed by Vickers in 1924. Made by Sperry gyroscope Co. in 1942.
Marks: Computer for Height of Anti Aircraft MKI, GEC 1942, REG No 730.

Object Title: Spirograph drawing kit, 1976
Spirograph drawing kit, with instruction booklet, sample drawings sheets, pens, disks, and packaging, sample drawings by Professor Allan Bromley, paper / plastic / metal, made by Denys Fisher (Eng) Ltd, England, 1976 Complete in original box, with instruction booklet, sample drawings sheets, pens, all disks. Plus sample drawings by Professor Allan Bromley. In generally very good condition. In 1962, Denys Fisher, an engineer from Leeds, England, invented the Spirograph whilst working in his family business, King Fisher Engineering. Three years later the educational toy which was to make him fortune was finally brought to fruition. Originally, the Spirograph was an idea for a pattern making machine for use in industry which Fisher had worked on to ensure a high degree of mathematical precision. When he hit the problem on trying to find a way to apply the invention to industry, he took his invention home much to the delight of his family who were were captivated by the colourful and intricate designs. So curious that Fisher decided to manufacture his invention as a educational toy.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Wang 362E electronic calculator, 1963 - 1973
Electronic desktop calculator, 362E, metal / plastic / electronic components, made by Wang Laboratories Inc, Massachusetts, United States of America, c.1968 There are two parts and a set of interconnecting cables to this object. The larger part is an aluminium case with ventilation slots, a blacked metal panel with labels, a carry handle, interconnection sockets and a power switch. The smaller part is a desktop calculator type panel in beige plastic having a matrix of keys and a red transparent panel behind which are a set of "nixie-tube" numeric displays. The keyboard has 3 blocks of square keys. The left block has 4 rows of function keys. In the top row of the left block are two toggle switches, one labelled "on" and the other labelled "Prod/Accum", a square-root key and an x^2 key. In the second row are an e^x, a log-e of x, and a divide = key. The third row has a "Clear Adder", a "-", and an "enter" key. The fourth row has a "Recall Adder", a "+" and a "X=" key. The central block has the numeric keys. In the top row are the "7", "8" and "9" keys. In the second row are the "4", "5" and "6" keys. In the third row are the "1", "2" and "3" keys. In the bottom row are a rectangular "0" and a square decimal point key. The right hand block has a "Clear Display" and a ""Change sign" keys, a second set of "Clear Adder", "Recall Adder", "-" and "+" keys and the memory store and recall keys.
Marks: Electronics pack: Wang Calculator, 362E Electronic Package, Manufactured by Wang Laboratories, Inc., Tewksbury, Mass, USA. Keyboard: Wang Calculator, 360K Keyborad, Manufactured by Wang Laboratories, Inc., Tewksbury, Mass, USA.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Madas calculating machine, 1908
Mechanical calculator, arithmometre, Madas calculating machine, metal, made by H W Egli S A Calculating Machines, Zurich, Switzerland, 1908 Metal calculating device with sloping brass operating panel, one foot missing, and black painted metal cover. The MADAS front panel has two sections. At the top is a sliding strip with 16 results widows, 9 rotation counters used in multiplication and a bell. At the right hand end of this sliding section are two levers for zero setting the results and the rotation counters. In the lower section of the front panel are 8 slides used for setting the numbers to be used. There is also a crank for adding the numbers to the results window each turn of which adds the current set number to the result so that it is used in all four species of arithmetic. Addition/multiplication or subtraction/divsion are selected by a pair of levers at the left side below the bell.

Object Title: Abney type pocket level and clinometer, 1945 - 1955

The spirit level bubble is centred when the object is in the sight and this establishes the angle of elevation which is then read off the scale.

Object Title: Canon Pocketronic handheld electronic calculator, 1965 - 1975
Electronic handheld calculator with case, Pocketronic, plastic / metal / electronic components, made by Canon, Japan, c.1970 Handheld electronic calculator with thermal printing mechanism which functions as the display. In the top of the calculator is a slot for installing thermal printing ribbons supplied as pre-packaged cartridges. On the top face of the calculator is a black label insert with Canon Pocketronic embossed onto it. The printing ribbon insert and the label are on a raised section of the calculator, below which is a transparent plastic display window through which entered numbers and results printed onto the printing ribbon can be seen. On the lower half of the calculator body is a grey keyboard area with an "On/Off" slide switch, and a matrix of 5 rows x 4 columns of keys. The top row has three blue keys marked "C", "Cl" and "X". The second row has three white numeric keys marked "7", "8", "9" and a blue key marked [divide]. The third row has three white numeric keys marked "4", "5", "6" and a blue key marked "-". The fourth row has three white numeric keys marked "1", "2", "3" and a blue key marked "+". The fifth row has two white numeric keys marked "0" and [decimal point] and a blue key marked "=". The 4 rows of numeric keys are contained in a matrix of white ruled lines. The object includes a grey vinyl pouch, instructions sheet glued to back, instructions booklet, thermal printing tapes, AC adaptor/battery charger, all in original, but masking-taped, packaging.
Marks: Canon Pocketronic

Handheld electronic calculator, scientific, SR-51-II, plastic / electronic components, made by Texas Instruments, United States of America, c.1976 Handheld electronic calculator in black plastic case with black plastic key panel thirteen (?) digit 7-segment LED display under a red transparent cover. The red plasmatic inlay housing the LED display also has a black "on/off" slide switch and the name Texas Instruments name and logo embossed onto it. On the black plastic key panel is a matrix of 8 rows x 5 columns of keys. The top row has 5 black keys marked "2nd", "sin", "cos", "tan" and "CLR". The second row has 5 black keys marked "INV", "%", "ln x" e^x, and [xth root of y]. The third row has 5 black keys marked [swap x and y], [x^2], [square root of x], "1/x" and [y^x]. The fourth row has 4 black keys marked [sigma +], "EE", "(", ")" and a yellow key marked [divide]. The fifth row has 1 black keys marked "STO", 3 white numeric keys marked "7", "8", "9" and a yellow key marked "X". The sixth row has one black key marked "RCL", three white numeric keys marked "4", "5", "6" and a yellow key marked "-". The seventh row has one black key marked "SUM", three white numeric keys marked "1", "2", "3" and a yellow key marked "+". The eighth row has one black key marked "CE", three white numeric keys marked "0", [decimal point], "+/-" and a yellow key marked "=". Object Title: Zero-setting compensating planimeter
Planimeter with case and instruction booklet, zero-setting compensating, metal / plastic / glass / paper / polyurethane, Tamaya Technics Inc, Tokyo, Japan, mid-20th century. This object is a Zero-setting Compensating Planimeter in a blacked metal case with polyurethane foam cutout instrument support in body of case and lid, plus instruction manual. Note: polyurethane is breaking down. Similar to a polar planimeter, the supporting arm is anchored to the work table with a short cylinder having a sharp point like a compass needle. It is linked to the tracing arm with a ball headed pin that forms an elbow hinge, locking it into the vernier carriage. The vernier carriage holds the accumulator wheel and vernier in a transparent plastic box which may be positioned along the tracing arm for the scale of the curve being measured. The accumulator wheel is the moving part that touches the table. At the tracing end the arm has a magnifying glass cursor. As the pointer is moved around the perimeter of the curve whose area is being measured the steel rim rolls forwards or backwards and skids sideways. The scale is on the wheel itself, and indicates how far the wheel has turned. The final dial reading represents the sum of all the rim's rolling motions. This number is proportional to the area of the region.
Marks: The tracing arm has the instrument number: 8306, and a scale marked from 4 to 16 in fine gradations of ten marks between each numbered scale. There is a calibration chart with the instrument.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Sikes' hydrometer, 1875 - 1899
Hydrometer with case, Sikes', brass / glass / wood / fabric / bone, made by J J Hicks, London, England, late 19th century Sikes' Hydrometer - Various parts in a red velvet lined purpose built wooden box with bone inlaid label. Box contains floatation sphere with ballast and a tail with graduated scale, a set of extra masses, a thermometer and two wooden rules. Accompanied by a book a tables and directions for use. There are numerous manufacturers of the Sikes' hydrometer. The present Hicks version would be considered the deluxe model as it contains two slide rules for temperature compensation.
Marks: Sikes' Hydrometer J.J. Hicks, 8, 9 & 10 Hatton Garden, London, Eng. on bone ornament inlaid into lid of box J.J. Hicks, 8, 9 & 10 Hatton Garden, on edge of rules numbers indicating masses, and graduated scales on float and rules.

Object Title: Allbrit planimeter
Polar planimeter in case, Allbrit, steel, /plastic / glass / leatherette, W.F. Stanley, London, mid-20th century. This object is an Amsler-type polar Planimeter in a blue velvet lined leatherette case. A supporting arm is anchored to the work table with a short cylinder having a sharp point like a compass needle. It is linked to the tracing arm with a ball headed pin that forms an elbow hinge. The tracing arm has at one end a carriage consisting in a pair of supports that hold between them the accumulator wheel and vernier. This carriage may be positioned along the tracing arm for the scale of the curve being measured. The accumulator wheel is the moving part that touches the table. At the tracing end the arm has a magnifying glass cursor. As the pointer is moved around the perimeter of the curve whose area is being measured the steel rim rolls forwards or backwards and skids sideways. The scale is on the wheel itself, and indicates how far the wheel has turned. The final dial reading represents the sum of all the rim's rolling motions. This number is proportional to the area of the region.
Marks: The accumulator wheel and vernier carriage has the instrument number: 38870. The tracing arm has a scale marked from 21 to 68 in fine gradations of ten marks between each numbered scale. The case has a calibration chart glued into its lid.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Ashcroft planimeter, 1882 - 1910
Planimeter with case, Coffin's Patent, stainless steel / wood, made by the Ashcroft Manufacturing Company, United States of America, 1882-1910 This object is an Ashcroft (Coffin's Patent) Planimeter consisting in two components. Object Title: Bow planimeter, 1875 - 1899
Planimeter with case, Amsler bow type, stainless steel / leatherette, made by the American Steam Gauge Company, Boston, Massachusetts, United States of America, late 19th century Amsler bow type Planimeter in purple velvet lined leatherette box. It has two rods joined by a hinge with a rotating steel wheel at the hinge which is dragged and rotated as the pointer at the end of the tracing rod is drawn around the area to be measured. The end of the other rod is supported by a short cylindrical mass. The whole is contained in a purpose built purple velvet lined leatherette case with rounded ends. This type of planimeter was used for calculating the mean effective pressure (MEP) of a steam engine. Steam pressure is indicated on a diagram or "card" in which the x-axis is the piston position as it moves through the engine stroke, and the y-axis records the pressure within the cylinder. Once the diagram has been recorded the area enclosed by the diagram is measured with the planimeter. The result is then divided by the length of the engine stroke to get the MEP.
Marks: on case: Made by American Steam Gauge Co., Boston, Mass
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Bygrave position line slide rule, 1925 - 1935
Cylindrical navigational slide rule with case, Bygrave type AML Position Line Mark IIA No 546. metal / paper / rubber, metal, made by Henry Hughes & Son Ltd, England, c. 1930 This is a Bygrave type Position Line (navigation) calculator. It consists in three concentric cylinders, the innermost having a long spiral scale of logarithmic tangents, the middle scale being logarithmic cosines and the outer having two pointers. It assists a navigator to obtain "position lines from sextant observations". The calculation of the spherical triangle is reduced to the solution of two right-angled spherical triangles so that the trigonometric functions can be represented in logarithmic form.
Marks: A.M.L. Position Line Slide Rule, Mark IIA, No.546 Patent No.162895

Object Title: Goodman's planimeter, 1915 - 1925
Hatchet planimeter with case and instruction sheet, Goodman's, stainless steel / leatherette / paper, made by Jackson Bros Ltd, Leeds, England, c. 1920 Goodman's Planimeter - stainless steel, curved "hatchet" planimeter in blue velvet-lined leatherette case with instruction sheet. It consists of a lightly curved rod with its ends bent into right angles. One end is flat allowing the instrument to be supported in a short cylindrical plinth so that it can be used to trace out the area enclosed by a curve using a sharp "tracing point" at the other end. The product of the displacement of the flattened end caused by the tracing and the length of the rod gives an approximation of the area bounded by the region traced.
Marks: Goodman's Patent on actual planimeter Goodman's Patent Planimeter, Jackson Bros, Ltd, Leeds stamped on inside of case
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Schoty [Russian abacus], 1945 - 1955
Abacus, (schoty], wood / wire, maker unknown, Russia, mid-20th century Black sloped wooden frame with slightly bowed wires to let the beads bunch to either side. There are 12 rows of ten beads on most wires except for two wires with four each. These are for ¼ rouble calculations, and early versions for ¼ kopek calculations. The rows of ten beads consist in four natural coloured beads on either side of two central black stained beads. The bowed wires mean that the beads stay to either edge of the device when shifted during operation. The Russian abacus - the Schoty - is not a well known device compared with the soroban or suanpan. Its use is somewhat different giving that it has ten beads in most columns and is thus operated in a rather different manner.

Object Title: The Adal Calculator
Spiral mechanical calculator, The Adal Calculator, metal, The Addall Company, Temple Courts, Temple Row, Birmingham, 1910. This object consists in a pair of metal disks and a cursor. The base is a flat aluminium disk with the numbers 00 to 99 around an outer ring which forms a lip. Concentric with this disk and laid upon it, is a thin brass disk which has one hundred small semi-circular indents and the numbers 00 to 99 in a ring around it. The main part of the upper disk is formed into a spiral of 11 turns. There is a tongue of brass attached to the central bolt and having a slot in which a steel ball slides as it accumulates turns of the spiral disk. The slot of the tongue has the numbers 1 to 11 marked on it at intervals equivalent to the step between each turn of the spiral. At its further end is a small clamp which holds it at the zero point of the outer ring so that it acts as a stop for the rotation of the accumulating spiral disk. The whole calculator is held in the flat of the hand. It is a simple adder to 1199 with addends 1-99. The spiral disk is turned by a stylus set into the indent of the number to be added until it reaches the stop. As each number is added the spiral disk rotates and the small steel ball slides in the slot in the tongue indicating the hundreds count of the accumulated result. The total result is thus the number indicated on the tongue (being the hundreds digit) plus the number indicated in the end gap of the stop.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Line-level amplifier, 1973 - 1980

Object Title: Dual turntable, 1968 - 1974
Record turntable, metal / wood / plastic / electronic components, made by Dual, used by Tristram Cary, England, 1968-1974 This object is one of a pair of Dual brand turntables used in the performance of the electronic music composition "Trios" by Tristram Cary. Cary recorded several copies of a 12" LP record with segments of his electronic music using his transcription record cutting machine. Two of these copies were then used in the performance. Each record was played back on one of the pair of Dual turntables each of which was operated by one of Cary's sons. Tracks on the records were selected according to the throw of a pair of dice. Cary then operated a synthesiser and mixer as a live treatment and mix so that every performance of the work was uniquely different.
Marks: Dual
