Object Title: EMS 8 octave filter bank, 1973
EMS 8 octave filter bank, metal / plastic / electronic components, made by Electronic Music Studios, used by Tristram Cary, England, 1973 The 8 octave filter bank is a device developed by EMS for use with their Synthi 100 system. This version has an extra set of outputs for use with non-Synthi 100 based systems and was used with the various synthesisers in Tristram Cary's private studio in Adelaide. It consists of a 19" (45cm) rack mounted cream-enamelled metal case with controls and output connector sockets on the front panel. The front panel is divided into two parts; the right hand part has 10 output connector sockets which make available the rectified signal level of that component of the audio frequency spectrum at the centre frequency specified by the 8 octaves of the filter bank. There are also a signal input and output connectors. On the left half of the front panel are the gain potentiometers for the eight frequency bands centred at each of the filters' 8 octaves. The octave centre frequencies are 63Hz, 125Hz, 250Hz, 500Hz, 1000Hz, 2000Hz 4000Hz and 8000Hz. Most synthesisers were able to delivers signals to about 10KHz so this range was all that was needed. The EMS specifications for the Synthi 100 indicate that the Octave Filter Bank "consists of eight resonating filters, fixed-tune one octave apart, in the range 62.5 Hz - 8 KHz, separately controllable."
Marks: 8 Octave Filter Bank Various control labels.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Dawe frequency meter counter timer type 3000AR, 1972 - 1976
Dawe digital frequency meter type 3000AR, metal / glass / plastic / electronic components, made by Dawe, used by Tristram Cary, England, 1972-1976 The Dawe Digital Frequency Meter, Counter and Timer type 3000AR is a device for measuring the frequency of audio signals used with the various synthesisers in Tristram Cary's private studio in Adelaide. It consists in a 19" (45cm) rack mounted cream-enamelled metal case with controls and digit display on the front panel. The front panel is divided into two parts, the right hand part has the controls that set up the meter so that it measures in the range required for the input signal. It has input signal banana plug connectors, two position switches for Normal mode or Accumulate mode operation and for Auto operate or Hold last value state. It has switches to Start, Stop and Reset the count and a rectangular saddle-shaped power switch. On the left hand half of the front panel there are five Nixie tube digit displays and a sixth masked place for a Nixie tube. These show the value of the frequency or the number of counted pulses depending on the mode the instrument is set to. The Dawe appears to have been supplied as part of the original complement of devices included in the EMS Synthi 100. Photographs of the Synthi 100 in the EMS Putney studio (Peter Zinovieff's private studio) show a Synthi 100 with a six digit version of the Dawe frequency counter. Photographs of other Synthi 100s variously show Dawe Frequency Meters or other devices in the same space on the Synthi 100's central panel. The EMS Synthi 100 Specifications show, under Items from other Manufacturers: Dawe 3000 AR/6 Digital Frequency Meter Brief details as follows: Crystal frequency: 100 KHz ca. 0.002 % Frequency Measurement: Range-0-1 MHz Accuracy - ca.1 digit ca. crystal accuracy Gating Time-1 ms to 10 seconds Period Measurement: Range 0-300 KHz , Time Units 1 10s to 10 ms, Gating Period - 1/7 to 1,000 cycles of input frequency Time Measurement: Range 10s - 10 secs (nearly four months)
Marks: Digital Frequency Meter, Counter and Timer type 3000AR DAWE
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Custom-built digital sequencer for audio synthesisers, 1976
Custom-built voltage sequencer, metal / plastic / electronic components, maker unknown, used by Tristram Cary, Australia, 1976 This is a custom built digital voltage sequencer with memory used in Tristram Cary's electronic music studio. It is housed in a grey green enamelled metal 19" (45cm) rack mounted box and would have been used to control the frequencies of a voltage controlled oscillator in producing electronic music. It consists in a number of modules that produce the controls and signals that make up its output. The front panel of the device has a set of control blocks laid out on it by which the sequencer is set up and run. 1: Clock control block: Initially a clock control would be set up. This has several toggle switches and a potentiometer. One of the toggle switches selects for the internal clock or an externally supplied clock. The internal clock frequency is controlled by the potentiometer. It can be set to run in forward or reverse modes. A push button switch allows the clock signal to be generated with each push of the button. 2: Sequence Start / End block: This block has two sets of four switches each accompanied by an LED indicator. 3: Voltage setting blocks: there are two blocks Voltage A and Voltage B which set up the assignment of voltage levels to each position of the sequence. Voltage A has 256 levels of voltage set by 8 binary switches, accompanied by LED indicators. The value set by these switches is written into memory by a pushbutton switch. To the right of these 8 switches is a potentiometer marked Scale which sets the voltage range from which each digital numerical range is a proportion. To the right of that is the voltage output connector socket. The Voltage B block has six switches which sets one of 64 values for conversion to a voltage level. Otherwise it functions in the same manner as the Voltage A block. 4: Triggers block: Below the voltage setting blocks are a pair of triggering blocks that set the triggering, or start event, of the A and B setting voltage blocks. Each of these triggers can be set off by one or other of two momentary toggle switches. Their outputs are made available at connector sockets and can be set for either the EMS or Moog synthesisers. 5: At the top left of the panel is a set of 16 LED indicators that show the progress of the sequence. There is a label bottom centre with what may be the initials of the maker and the date of construction, this consists in "TAHL 76". If the 76 is a date code then the sequencer was probably made in Adelaide in 1976 after Cary had been at the Elder Conservatorium for two years. The capacity to drive both EMS and Moog synthesisers is also suggestive of this because the Elder Conservatorium had a Moog synthesiser in its studio as well as Cary's EMS equipment.
Marks: TAHL 76 Various function labels.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Four channel hand-held mixer, 1970 - 1975
Hand-held four-channel mixing device, metal / plastic, probably made by Tristram Cary, Australia, 1970-1975 This object is probably a hand-held four-channel mixing device for use with two tape-recorders or turntables while performing live electronic music. Object Title: Custom mixer panel, 1968 - 1972
Mixer panel, custom built, metal / plastic / electronic components, maker unknown, used by Tristram Cary, England, 1968-1972 This is a hand-built mixer panel used in Tristram Cary's Fressingfield studio. It is mounted on a white enamel coated metal plate (approx 30 x 45cm) with numerous controls built into it. Across the top it has a zigzag row of 8 4-position rotary selector switches that select which of four 'treatment return' fader channels are sent to 8 'treatment ratio' potentiometers. The outputs of these ratio controls are buffered using one op-amp integrated circuit per channel and the buffered signals are then sent to the 8 fader controls via bass and treble filter potentiometers. There are also 4 faders labelled 'Main Faders' which have been disconnected but were probably either treatment send faders or recorder and amplifier sends. The faders are all slider-style ribbon potentiometers, with level settings marked in paint in a grid surrounding each fader set. The rotary controls are all standard potentiometers with black plastic knobs on their shafts. There are two cue lamps and two 'Start' toggle switches on the panel between the treatment return faders and the main faders. There are also labels in dymotape at some of the controls which indicate their purpose. On the reverse are the working elements of the various control components, plus a circuit board having the 8 buffer ICs.
Marks: Dymotape labels
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Control desk selector panel from Tristram Cary's studio, 1958 - 1962
Selector panel and control panel, metal / plastic / paper, maker unknown, used by Tristram Cary, England, 1958-1962 This pair of objects are two metal panels used in Tristram Cary's studio as part of his signal routing system. The larger panel was built into the desk above the mixer and was probably used to select tape recorder and other audio signals to one of the fader channels on the mixer. This selection was done with a 6 position rotary switch (no longer attached) and the channels are labelled with coloured paper dots. It also has 4 push-button switches that are labelled "Osc. Remote Control". The smaller panel has 10 holes drilled into it, 6 are labelled 1 - 6 and 4 are labelled with the same coloured dots used on the selector of the larger panel. It is likely that this panel had indicator lamps or potentiometers inserted into the holes.
Marks: Dymo-tape labels

Object Title: Matrix patch panel from Tristram Cary studio, 1960 - 1969
Matrix patch panel, plastic / metal, maker unknown, used by Tristram Cary, England, 1960-1969 This is a patching matrix used in Tristram Cary's early studios. It was used to connect the line output from the main control panel to the Revox tape recorders and the mixer input for the monitoring speakers in the studio. It consists of a black metal panel with sixteen rows and sixteen columns of patch points, which are connected by small matrix pins. It is the same kind of patching matrix as was used in the VCS3 and presumably came from the same surplus equipment source or directly from EMS. Many of the matrix points are labelled with dymo tape indicating their signal source or destination.

Object Title: Patch panel from Tristram Cary's studio, 1964 - 1969
Patch panel, telephone jack type, metal / plastic, probably made by Tristram Cary, England, 1964-1969 This is a telephone-jack type patch panel used in Tristram Cary's early studios. It was used to connect various effects devices, eg, the echo unit, various filters with the Revox tape recorder bank and other monitoring instruments, including meters and an oscilloscope. It consists of a black metal panel with four offset rows of patch points, a pair of switches for meter input select to the upper right and a two position rotary switch for selecting left or right line input channels to the oscilloscope. Many of the jack points are labelled with coloured dymo tape indicating their signal source or destination.

Object Title: Transient waveform modifier, 1958 - 1962
Transient waveform modifier (envelope shaper), custom built, metal / plastic / electronic components i/ glass, probably made by Tristram Cary, England, 1958-1962 This is a hand-built device known as a Transient Waveform Modifier. A transient is a voltage waveform that is generated to trigger the envelope of a sound. The envelope shapes the amplification of an oscillator over a short period of time so that it sounds like it has been produced as a musical sound. This is the contour of the sound and is normally thought of as having an attack, decay, sustain and release period (ADSR). It appears to have been custom built either by or for Tristram Cary and was used in his early studios back as far as, at least, the Fressingfield studio in Suffolk in the UK. It is a black metal panel with sixteen control knobs arranged in four rows of four, with a set of labels between the upper and lower pairs of rows. Electronically, it consists of four independent channels each of which utilises one row of control knobs. Each row consists of two multi-pole switches and two potentiometers. Each row is numbered, in cream paint, from 1 at the top to 4 at the bottom. In the back of the metal plate are the electronics for the four channels. These consist of the body of the switches and the potentiometers, an EF40 pentode audio amplifier valve, and the necessary passive electronic components to connect everything up and shape the currents so that the device works. Functionally, this device is a version of the envelope generator used in most analogue audio synthesisers. It has controls: The left most control is a 6 position switch that sets the degree of differentiation performed on the signal. Differentiation causes the signal to be sharpened up and may be thought of as the "attack" rate (slew rate) of the control voltage envelope. This control sets the rise time or 'attack' of the envelope. The second control is a three position switch which determines whether the envelope waveform triggered by the transient continues to 'grow' (or rise) or 'die' and drop away (or releases). The third control is a variable potentiometer that sets the duration of the active period of the envelope, that is, it sets the hold period of the note being shaped by this signal. The right most control is a potentiometer labelled Low Level Set and is the level of the voltage held during its interim period or the voltage that it remains at between transient events.
Marks: Handwritten label: Transient Waveform Modifier
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Voltage controlled oscillator (VCO), 1962 - 1966
Voltage controlled oscillator (VCO) with ring modulator, custom built, metal / plastic / electronic components, probably made by Tristram Cary, England, 1962-1966 This is probably a hand-built and very early version of a device known as a ring modulator. It consists of a voltage controlled oscillator (the device which is at the heart of all analogue audio synthesis equipment) with a number of presettable voltage setting potentiometers selected with a large rotary switch. It is mounted in a black metal plate (approx 40 x 45cm) with numerous controls built into it. Across the top it has two rows of 12 presettable potentiometers which are wired to a 30 position rotary switch. The switch is set up to select from any one of the presets, two very finely resolvable potentiometers having vernier controls or a further four external voltage inputs. In the centre of the panel is a rectangular plastic panel with a white surface in which the two vernier controls are mounted. On the regions of the surface around each there are traces of control position markers written in chinagraph pencil. There is a voltage level meter to the right hand of this central panel. Below there are, from left to right, a single control knob, a two position rotatable switch, three output jacks, three columns of three control knobs for setting amplitudes of a square wave and (what appear to be) two triangle or sawtooth wave oscillators. The outputs of the three oscillators are summed together to produce an output signal. These controls have arrows in strips of white tape running between them indicating the connections of the circuits and the signal flow between them. Many of the controls are marked with coloured paper dots to enable the user to distinguish which controls appear at which outputs or contribute to those output signals. There are also labels in dymotape at some of the controls which indicate their purpose. On the reverse are the working elements of the various control components, plus several circuit boards, the functions of which are controlled by these components. The circuit boards consist of two printed wiring assemblies, which are probably off-the-shelf oscillators, and two prototype circuits built on strip board (Vero board). Each has an array of electronic components consisting of transistors and passive devices soldered onto it. There is an array of wires which connect up the various devices.
Marks: Various labels in dymo tape.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Reiby Hall gospel wagon, 1905 - 1970
Gospel wagon, and contents, wood / metal / rubber / glass / cloth / paper, made and used by Reiby Gospel Hall, Newtown, New South Wales, Australia, 1905-1970 A gospel wagon or prayer cart, used for evangelistic activity on streets, sidewalks and parks. The vehicle consists of a wooden crate with a hinged top lid. Four spoked wheels and a suspension unit (possibly from an old-style perambulator) are bolted to the floor of the cart. A wooden handle is attached at one end of the crate for pushing. The interior of the crate contains wiring for lighting as well as various leaflets (mostly for Reiby Hall), a prayer card and a loose glass light bulb fitting. Slats attached to the side suggest that the cart once contained a shelf. The crate is lettered in fading red and black paint on the lid and three sides.
Marks: See parts.

Object Title: Mullard Australian GM4140A Measuring Bridge, 1939
Measuring Bridge GM4140A, metal / plastic / wood / electronic components, made by Mullard Radio, Australia, 1939 This object is an instrument for measuring the capacitance or the resistance of passive components used in electronics. It is built into a timber box with leatherette covering. The front panel is in black Bakelite. It has three sockets for connecting probes at the top. The left hand and centre pair are used for Capacitance measurements and the right hand and centre pair are used for Resistance measurements. Below these is the Mullard Radio Australia logo and below that is a glass device that is a "null point". Two rotary controls in Bakelite with labelled backing dress are set below these. The left hand one is a Range switch for selecting the capacitance or resistance range values. The right hand control is for adjusting the sensitivity of the device when measuring in any of these ranges. Below these switches is a large black Bakelite rotary control with finger indents and a white Bakelite backing dress with a double scale for adjusting the percentage of accuracy of the measurements This device is a measuring bridge which indicates the value of a resistive or capacitive component by balancing the unknown component with known values of resistance or capacitance selected by the range switch, the sensitivity control and the percentage difference control. When a balance is reached the current flowing through the bride is nulled out and the arrangement that replaces the traditional galvanometer shows a null position. In this case this arrangement consists in a high-gain pentode valve amplifier, which gives the whole measuring bridge a very high input impedance, thus significantly reducing its load on the component being measured and rendering it far more accurate. The pentode amplifier output then drives an electron beam tube (cathode-ray tube) indicator - the glass device at centre-top - which shows the null point, or balance between the unknown component and the comparison circuit values by a finely focused line presented in the florescent surface of the glass indicator. See: The Mullard Wireless Service Co., Ltd., "A.C. Measuring Bridge", J. Sci. Instrum. Vol.15, pp.383-384, 1938, which refers to the GM4140.
Marks: Mullard Radio Australia badge GM4140A - Made in Australia - Serial No.2019 indicator labels around controls
Categories: Electronic equipment|Measuring instruments|Audio and Visual Equipment|Measuring Instruments

Object Title: Calstan Multimeter, 1934 - 1944
Multimeter, Calstan, plastic / metal, made by Slade Precision Test Equipment, Croydon, New South Wales, Australia, c. 1939 This is an electronic test instrument manufactured sometime between 1931 and 1939. It is built into a timber box with a leatherette cover. The front panel is brown Bakelite and is offset into the front of the box. It has a fan-shaped moving coil meter and circuitry to allow it to display the value of DC and AC voltages in a circuit, the resistance (in ohms) of a component and the current (in milliamps) of the electrical power flowing in a circuit. Below the meter there is a potentiometer with a slotted screw-head set into the panel for calibration of the meter. The lower half of the front panel has a pair of octagonal Bakelite knobs, one at either side. The left hand one is for selecting the ohms range for the resistance meter and the right hand one is for fine adjustment of the ohms range. Between these two is a toggle switch for selecting the DC or AC voltmeter mode. There are four sockets for connecting probes to the device, two on either edge of a panel with a 12 position indicator switch that selects voltage scales for the voltmeter and amps scales for the milliamp meter. This also has an off position and an ohms position for the resistance meter.
Marks: Calstan 135, No. 1804 Slade Precision Instruments Croydon N.S.W.
Categories: Electronic equipment|Measuring instruments|Meters|Audio and Visual Equipment|Measuring Instruments

Object Title: Palec V.T.M. Vacuum Tube Voltmeter, 1951
Vacuum Tube Multimeter, (VTM), Palec, metal / plastic, made by Paton Electrical Pty Ltd, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1951 This object consists of an electronic package mounted in a metal box. The box is coated with a stippled enamel paint. In the centre of the face is a large meter mounted in a black Bakelite frame with an inverted-heart shaped window. The meter has two scales: one with graduations in Volts and the other with graduations in ohms. It has a fine needle pointer to indicate the values of measurements. The controls are located on the lower half of the front face of the box, mounted on a metal cover plate. On either side of this plate are mirrored rotary switches, and probe and ground connectors. Below the meter are a zero adjust and an ohms adjust potentiometer each having a hexagonal Bakelite knob. All the controls have labels indicating their functions etched into the surface of the cover plate and filled with a cream paint. There is a leather carrying strap attached to the top of the box by metal clamps.
Marks: Palec V.T. (Probe) Multimeter Model V.T.M. Serial No.372. Made in Australia by Paton Electrical Pty. Ltd. Sydney.

Object Title: Windsor transistor radio, 1952 - 1962
Radio, transistor operated, portable, metal / plastic, made by Windsor Radio, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, c. 1957 Radio, transistor operated, portable, Windsor Radio, c.1957. This is a portable transistor radio made under the Windsor brand by the Albert Wright workshop in Hurlstone Park. It comes in a wooden case covered with dark grey leatherette, metal (brass) feature strips and a thickly woven cloth speaker cover. It has a flat strip handle of metal attached by bolts to the upper sides. It has two flat cream plastic knurled knobs, one of a large diameter with labels indicating the stations or the transmitting frequency approximate positions which is for tuning the receiver, and one of smaller diameter for setting the volume. It is constructed from early printed circuit boards that use transistors for the amplification stages. There are also a tuneable capacitor for selecting the station and the necessary passive electronic components for its functioning. It has a Rola speaker, its own internal ferrite rod antenna and a power transformer. It used OC71 transistors, the first commercially available transistor, made by Mullard.
Marks: Windsor

Object Title: Windsor Radio chassis, 1945 - 1955
Radio receiver chassis, valve operated, metal / plastic, made by Windsor Radio, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, c.1950 This item is the chassis and front panel with control knobs of a Windsor De-Luxe valve radio from c.1950. The front panel consists in a glass plate mounted in a metal frame. It has the station identification numbers of the radio transmitting stations for the states of Australia set across its range. A pointer hangs down from the top supported by a stretched wire that is turned by the tuning pulley operated by the tuning knob on the front panel. The tuning and volume knobs are of white plastic. It has a metal base plate on which are mounted three valves in sockets, several tuneable inductors in tin cans, a tuning capacitor for tuning-in the transmitting station and a power transformer. Underneath the metal base plate are the passive electronic components required for it to function.
Marks: Windsor De-Luxe radio station call-signs for different states in Australia.

Object Title: Australian Window Glass/Pilkington ACI/ Viridian (archive), 1925 - 1985
(1) Better Glass for Better Living (Pilkington ACI Limited): Blue vinyl folder, with an introduction entitled 'Two New Ways To Promote The Magic Of Glass', by Babette Hayes (see also the enclosed sheet 'About Babette Hayes Design' for brief biographical material http://www.babettehayes.com.au/about-babette-hayes [accessed 27/4/09]. Promotional text on 'Rialto', and 'Sirocco' glass. There are 3 samples of 'Rialto' glass and 1 sample of 'Sirocco'. Rialto is defined as "a bold dynamic pattern in keeping with a return to more romantic moods", and Sirocco as "a gentle, ever swirling pattern inspired by sand drifts, designed to complement today's interest in natural textures". (2) Large photographs (framed): (a) Coloured aerial photograph of Australian Window Glass Manufacturers Pty Ltd., Sydney (1938). Euston Road is located in the foreground; (b) Viridian Factory Site Plan (drawn 23/1/1960) showing factory site bounded by Euston Road and Maddox Street, Alexandria. The plan shows the layout of the factory, and other firms who were located on the site (scale 1":100'); (c) Black and white line drawing entitled 'Alexandria Basic Manufacturing Process' (n.d.). The drawing shows the principal stages in flat-sheet glass at Alexandria (raw materials - batch mixing - batch silo - furnace - forehearth - rolling - lehr - testing - storage - despatch); (d) Black and white drawing entitled 'Plan View of ER1 [furnace] Tank'. Plan view of furnace tank illustrating the regenerators on the left and the 3 ports on the right. At the refining end of the furnace, can be seen the canal (constructed in 1976) that connects the Forebay to the Forehearth and then to the lehr (an oven for annealing glass); Black and white drawing showing a plan for the operation known as the 'firing of the furnace on the left side'; A black and white line drawing showing the elevation of the Regenerators as viewed from the furnace ForeBay end; Aerial photograph showing the factory (c.1950s - 1960s). The factory boundary is marked by a black border line. (3) Dornbusch Gravuren GMBH (see: http://www.dornbusch-gravuren.de/en_docs/inhalt_portrait.html) [accessed 13/5/09] swatch books: 1 of 17 illustrating the patterns used on embossing rollers and plates, and printing rollers. The swatch covers show a printer/engraver seated inspecting a pattern on the roller. An example of the pattern can be found inside each swatch. (4) Framed water colour entitled 'Ilustration of Sheet Glass Manufacture'. The painting is by W.K. Mitchell (1968). Each industrial item in the painting is named, and the process of glass manufacture can be followed by viewing the painting in conjunction with item 3(c) above. (5) Framed black and white photographs of south and north side of furnace ports (20/7/1966).

Object Title: Two hats from Kiribati, 1960 - 1963
Hats (2), pandanus leaves / fibre / vegetable dyes, maker unknown, Fanning Island, Kiribati, 1960-1963 Two hats made from pandanus leaves with fibre stitching and decorative patterns coloured in vegetable dyes. The first hat is conical in shape with a squared top. Each pandanus leaf is individually chain stitched and two are dyed pink and arranged in a triangular shape. The rim is also dyed pink and hand stitched with beige fibre thread. The inside of the hat is reinforced with a circular band of pandanus leaves and a fibre tie is attached to support the chin. The second hat also has a squared top, conical middle and flared sides with pink and purple coloured pandanus leaves, and a pink and green 'V' and 'W' shape at the flared ends attached with pink and green hand stitched fibre thread. The rim of the hat is dyed pink and hand stitched with beige and pink thread. On the inside of the hat is a reinforced circular band of pandanus leaves.
Marks: No marks
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Shell collar from Kiribati, 1960 - 1963
Shell collar (necklace), cowrie shells / seeds / elastic cord, Fanning Island, Kiribati, 1960-1963 U-shaped neck collar formed from five layers (one above the other) of cowrie shells tightly bound on clear elastic cord. The top and bottom rows are framed by small brown seeds. A chain of single cowrie shells at the top of the 'U' with a piece of clear string is used for joining. Five large cowrie shells are evenly distributed and hang at the base of the collar for decoration.

Object Title: Turkmen Beshir carpet from Central Asia, 1845 - 1855
Carpet, 'Khanate of Bukhara', knotted wool, made by a Turkmen Beshir weaver, western Central Asia, c. 1850 Knotted wool carpet, with intact flat weave ends, featuring in the field a variation on the 'herati' pattern borrowed from Iran (Persia). Typically for Turkmen rugs and carpets, and carpets from this area, the principal colours are a glowing red on a dark blue ground with natural and light blue accents.

Object Title: Arab-Khamseh 'Chicken' carpet, 1865 - 1875
Carpet, knotted wool, made by an Arab-Khamseh weaver, southern Iran (Persia), c. 1870 A symmetrically knotted wool carpet with a wool warp, featuring three hooked medallions containing birds and animals around a central slender cross form. An indigo-coloured field is filled with vertical rows of birds facing stylised tree forms with small rosettes and 'S' shapes in the spaces between. The birds have the rare feature of two eyes; usually these bird motifs have one or no eyes. The field is surrounded by an unusual stepped design while the main border is classic Khamseh. Two minor borders feature the rose and vine design and the edgings are of different coloured chequerboard.
Marks: No marks.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Audio recording and production equipment used by the ABC from late 1940s to early 1960s., 1948 - 1950

Object Title: Galileo's telescope (reproduction), 2009
Galileo's telescope, reproduction, leather / wood / glass, made by Antiques of Science & Technology, Wakefield, Massachusetts, United States of America, 2009 "Galileo's gilded leather presentation telescope replicated very precisely for dimensions and materials according to the original in Florence Italy, IMSS inventory #2428. Object Title: Archive of material relating to the Sydney Mod scene in the 1980s, 1966 - 1988
Archive of material relating to the Sydney Mod sub-culture in the 1980s including magazines and fanzines (15), newsletters (7), flyers and invitations (30), press articles (51), photographic negatives (315), proof sheets (12), photographs, colour and black and white (142), diaries (2), paper / plastic, collected by Kirstin Sibley, various makers and producers, Australia and the UK, 1966 - 1988 Collection of ephemera relating to the mod revivalist subculture of the 1980s in Sydney, Australia compiled by Kirstin Sibley. The collection includes a series of photographs (and 35mm negatives) taken by Sibley of her mod social circle at various locations around Sydney between 1984 and 1985. Sibley's school diaries recorded her social activities, the newspaper and magazine clippings from English and Australian magazines provided fashion and style advice. The collection of locally produced fanzines and newletters kept the mod and related subcultures informed of the fashions, music and events associated with this scene. The flyers and invitations documented the range of social activities including band gigs, 60s inspired nightclub events, scooter runs and soccer friendlies.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Letters related to workplace suggestions, 1934 - 1956
Letters and photographs, suggestions to improve workplace design and safety in electricity substations, Ronald Ball and Sydney County Council, paper, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1934-1956 Dated 1934, photograph of Ronald George Ball, in suit and tie, with his wife and baby son outside a house. Dated 10 December 1937, and addressed to Mr R G Ball at 35 Arthur Street, Carlton, letter of appointment to the position of electrical fitter with the Sydney County Council Electricity Undertaking (SCC), signed by General Manager H R Forbes Mackay and typed on letterhead that includes a drawing of the Queen Victoria Building, at 457 George Street, where the SCC had its offices. The rate of pay was to be six pounds per week, and conditions of appointment included provision of a birth certificate, to ensure that the employee would 'cease to be a member of the Council's service upon reaching the age of sixty-five years'. The letter instructed Mr Ball to present himself to the Medical Officer on 14 December for a medical examination; a hand-written annotation in the margin notes 'fit' followed by the date 14.12.37 and initials, presumably of the Medical Officer. Dated 8 May 1950, handwritten letter from R Ball at West AC Sub Depot, Canterbury, addressed in formal style to the Chairman of the SCC Suggestions Board. The suggestion in the letter was designed to address the problem of emergency hand-operated winding gear in substations being compromised on occasion by theft of a chain that was necessary to its operation. The substations affected were part of the 33 kV distribution system containing 'F&P switchgear', which probably refers to equipment made by Ferguson and Pailin. The fix Ball suggested was to replace the chain with gears. Letters dated 18 March 1941, 2 April 1942, 15 December 1942, 22 August 1944, 10 April 1946, 17 October 1947, 13 November 1953, 4 August 1954, 24 May 1955 and 29 February 1956, addressed to Mr Ball. All letters are typed on letterhead, most bearing the SCC badge, which consists of the words THE SYDNEY COUNTY COUNCIL around a circle containing representations of the Sun (with the word HEAT), a fuel torch (with the word LIGHT) and a rearing horse (with the word POWER) and the words PERACTIS POSTERA PRAESTENT (which can be translated as 'Let the future excel the past') on a ribbon. Most are signed by General Managers: R Vine-Hall (1941 and 1942), DJ Nolan (1944 and 1946), GS Boyd (1947) and CE Ranger (1953, 1954 and 1956). One is signed by Deputy General Manager JCA Fraser (1955). They thank Mr Ball for a total of 11 suggestions, 10 of which were accepted. They commend him for his interest in his work, and refer to monetary rewards varying from two to ten pounds and totalling 46 pounds. The suggestions were assigned numbers from 737 (for one made in 1940 regarding electrostatic reconditioning of transformer oil, which led to in-house experiments and seeking of advice from overseas before it was rejected in 1942) to 2152 for the one accepted in 1956 (screening of low voltage switchboards in substations). Letter dated 19 June 1950, typed on plain paper and signed by substation engineer L V Molloy, thanking Mr Ball for his 'ingenuity and enthusiasm' in instigating a new approach to the application of end caps to busbars. Dated 1951, photograph of Ronald Ball, dressed in casual clothes, with his grand-daughter. Letter dated 29 February 1956, typed on letterhead paper, addressed to Mr Ball and signed by R Hahn, Secretary of the Suggestions Board. This letter acknowledges receipt of a suggestion for improved safety of apparatus earthing. Undated small SCC envelope, neither stamped nor franked, addressed to Mr R Ball, Maintenance Fitter, Substation Branch. This may have contained the February 1956 letter, which has the same form of address. The white envelope bears, in green: the word ELECTRICITY written vertically the full length of the left hand edge; return address for SCC at bottom left; and at top left a sketch of the head and hand of an elderly bespectacled woman with a finger on the switch of
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Design archive, John Andrews/John Andrews International, 1962 - 1992
The archive is a selection from a large collection stored at Hamiltons Bluff Vineyard, Canowindra, NSW. The archive consists of: Transparencies, negatives and photographic prints documenting projects undertaken by John Andrews and John Andrews International 1962 to 1992. As well as records of completed buildings, this collection includes copy photos of presentation drawings and other documents, as well as photos of models etc. A framed and mounted set of award citations for Gund Hall, Harvard: 1. American Institute of Architects Honor Award, 1973. 2. The Bartlett Award for 'access and useability for handicapped persons', 1973. 3. Design in Steel Award, American Iron and Steel Institute, 1973. A framed and mounted award citation for the American Express Tower, Sydney: Royal Australian Institute of Architects Sulman Award 'for a building of outstanding merit', 1983. A framed and mounted award citation for Scarborough College. Toronto: Royal Architectural Institute of Canada, 'Design Excellence 25 Year Award', 1989. Two presentation models of: 1. Octagon offices, Parramatta. 2. No.2 Bond Street, Sydney (unbuilt). A set of Australian and international journals containing reviews and features on Andrews' work. Original research/proposal reports for: Scarborough College Belconnen town centre and offices Building prospectuses, including some for unbuilt projects including No.2 Bond Street and the Darling Harbour Casino/Hotel. Mounted presentation photos and prints of: African Place, Expo 67 Toronto City Hall Guelph College student housing Belvedere Primary School Early work for John B Parkin, Toronto Scarborough College Miami Passenger Terminal Gund Hall, Harvard Cameron Offices, ACT American Express Tower, Sydney Australian High Court competition Merln (Hyatt) Hotel, Perth Little Bay housing. A set of photographic prints detailing the construction of the Cameron Offices, Belconnen. A framed watercolour pictorial elevation of Darling Harbour casino and hotel project. Two triangular pieces of tinted plexi-glass, as used on the American Express Tower and Callam Offices. Four documentary films: 'Architecture A Performing Art', 16mm col print 26 mins 'Building Gund Hall', colour 27 Min 'Scarborough College' 'Boston'. Concept, presentation, design, working and/or tender drawings of: Guelph College student housing, Ontario, Canada Miami Passenger Terminal, USA Gund Hall, Harvard, USA Intelsat Headquarters, Washington, USA. American Express Tower, Sydney. World Congress Centre and Hotel, Melbourne. Adelaide Station redevelopment (including hotel, convention and exhibition centres) Cameron Offices, Belconnen, ACT. Object Title: 'Jungle' wallpaper by Florence Broadhurst Wallpapers Ltd, 1971
Wallpaper lengths (3), 'Jungle', multi-colour screenprint on silver foil on paper, designed and made by Florence Broadhurst Wallpapers Ltd, Roylston Street, Paddington, New South Wales, Australia, 1971 Three lengths of panoramic wallpaper, multi-coloured 'Jungle' design, trimmed ready for hanging, screenprinted with white, green, black and grey inks on silver foiled paper, the three widths designed to form one panoramic wallpaper design titled 'Jungle', printed by Trevor Oxnam. Object Title: BOAC Speedbird poster by F H K Henrion, 1945 - 1955
Poster, airline advertising, 'BOAC / it's a small world by Speedbird', colour lithograph on paper, designed by F H K Henrion, London, United Kingdom, c. 1950 Poster design titled, 'BOAC / it's a small world by Speedbird', a colour lithograph poster on paper. The rectangular poster in portrait format depicts a blue Speedbird carrying merging global meridian lines and trailing a suite of flags of various nations banners from the front of the plane. A world map in yellow appears on a sea of blue below the Speedbird's route to the various nations: the USA, Australia and New Zealand are clearly marked. The route is depicted in the same vibrant blue colour used for the Speedbird airplane.
Marks: Signed 'Henrion' upper right. Text inscribed within poster, 'BOAC / it's a small world by Speedbird'
Provenance (Production): Maker: Henrion, F H K; London, England; 1945 - 1955|

Object Title: 1938 Empire Games poster, 1938
Poster, '1938 Empire Games / Sydney', colour lithograph on paper, designed by Charles Meere, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1938. Poster, 1938 Empire Games, colour lithograph on paper, designed by Charles Meere to advertise the 1938 Empire Games Sydney, rectangular poster in portrait format. The poster depicts a male athlete wearing black spiked shoes, white shorts with a red stripe down the side and a white T-shirt with a design of the Union Jack mid front. Object Title: 'Australia / Follow the Sun' poster, 1938
Poster, 'Australia / Follow the Sun 1938', colour photolithograph on paper, unidentified designer, issued by the Australian National Travel Association, Australia, 1938 Poster, 'Australia / Follow the Sun 1938', colour photolithograph on paper, issued by the Australian National Travel Association, poster depicts a yellow rising sun in the upper right corner and three large, smiling portraits of a man, woman and child in the foreground. The grey background depicts a black and white photograph of the ocean beach with many people swimming in the water. The main text reads: 'FOLLOW THE SUN / 1938' written in the sun, followed by 'AUSTRALIA / 150TH ANNIVERSARY CELEBRATIONS / SYDNEY / 26TH JANUARY TO / 25TH APRIL 1938'. At the bottom of the poster the texts reads: 'Particulars of Travel and / Bookings at Shipping Offices / and Travel Agencies'. In the middle of the bottom section of the poster is the kangaroo logo with the words 'Australian National Travel Association'. This is followed with 'Issued by the Australian National / Travel Association. - Offices:- London; / Los Angeles; Toronto; Welliington; Batavia; / Shanghai; Tokio; Paris; Cairo; Sydney / (Endeavour House, Macquarie Place)'

Object Title: Woman's yellow chyrpy (robe), Tekke Turkmen, 1875 - 1900
Chyrpy (robe), women's, wool / wool felt / silk / cotton, made by Tekke Turkmen, Turkmenistan, western Central Asia, late 1800s Yellow silk robe with silk lacing stitch (kesdi embroidery) in madder red, magenta, blue-black, green and white geometric motifs and flowers. Around the bottom of the robe is a wool magenta and green tassle replacement fringe. The inside of the coat is lined in cotton, block-printed with a madder red and ivory check design. Hanging from the back of the coat is a pair of false sleeves with tapered ends joined together by a horizontal strip of wool felt. There are two slits in the lower half of the coat at each side.
Marks: None

Poster, 'Be the Change', 6265/10000, silkscreen print on paper, designed and made by Shepard Fairey in Los Angeles for use during the Inauguration Ceremonies of President Barack Obama and Vice President Joe Biden on 20th January 2009 at Washington DC, United States of America, 2009 Rectangular poster depicting a silkscreen print of Barack Obama with Capitol Hill and the Whitehouse in the background, flanked by dense crowds on two diagonals in the foreground. Two lines in the formation of a 'V' across the middle of the poster is centred by an Obama - Biden circular logo featuring Capitol Hill with text around the outside. Words 'BE THE CHANGE' are printed horizontally at the top of the poster and 'JANUARY 20TH 2009' is printed horizontally at the bottom of the poster. Words in a circular direction on the centre logo read: 'INAUGURATION OF PRESIDENT AND VICE PRESIDENT / 2009' with the names 'OBAMA' and 'BIDEN' inside. The poster is printed in patriotic red, white and blue and these colours delineate Obama's face. The reverse of the poster is plain cream.
Marks: '6,265 / 10,000' hand written in pencil on the bottom left hand corner.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Fairey, Shepard; Los Angeles, California, USA; 2009|

Object Title: Interdata 70 minicomputer, 1972
Interdata 70 minicomputer, metal / plastic, made by Interdata Inc, Oceanport, New Jersey, United States of America, 1972, used by the Anglo-Australian Telescope, Coonabarabran, New South Wales, Australia, 1974-2008 The system consists of four rack mount cabinets and two free standing terminals, one of which is the original one while the other with the monitor is from the early 1980s. "The processor is an Interdata Model 70 minicomputer with the maximum 64Kb of core memory. This has a 16-bit word length, fast response to interrupts from up to 256 devices, 16 general purpose registers, and an extensive instruction set, including multiply, divide, and floating point operations. It is relatively fast; many instructions only take 1 microsecond. A 'memory protect' feature aids multiprogramming, where the memory partition of one program is protected against the activities of others. The control system uses 16- and 32-bit integer arithmetic and single precision floating point arithmetic. Nowhere does it have to resort to double precision point arithmetic despite the barely adequate 21-bit to 24-bit accuracy of single precision numbers. A wide range of peripherals is provided, including two disks, each of 2.5 million byte capacity, which are used continuously by the control system to move programs in and out of core, and a digital multiplexor I/O interface between the computer and most of the telescope devices." (Straede and Wallace, 1976)

Object Title: Batik shirt worn by the Hon Paul Keating, APEC, 1994
Shirt, mens, silk / cotton / aniline dyes, batik design by Iwan Tirta made by workmen and women from Iwan Tirta's workshop, worn by the Hon Paul J Keating at the 1994 APEC leaders meeting, Jakarta, Indonesia, 1994 Long-sleeved mens shirt made of silk with reinforced collar, front left-hand pocket, seven buttons down the front covered by a vertical silk flap and a single button on each cuff. The shirt is black with a design featuring the Australian coat of arms in indigo blue twice on the front and back, with gold and indigo blue native wildflowers, including the waratah, around the outside. All motifs are outlined in gold and sections of the floral pattern are filled with white stippling. The shirt is lined with black silk decorated with small, ornate floral and geometric motifs arranged in columns and is machine stitched. There is a split in both sides of the shirt which runs about one quarter of the overall length (from the upper thigh to the hip).
Marks: No marks
Provenance (History): User: Keating, Paul; Indonesia; 1994|

Object Title: Equipment associated with coin toll collecting apparatus used on the Sydney Harbour Bridge, 1989 - 2008
Documentation, spare parts and calibration equipment associated with coin toll collecting apparatus used on the Sydney Harbour Bridge including manuals and notes prepared by Roads and Traffic Authority staff (2), computer monitor, computer keyboard, computer mouse, computer hard drive, calibration unit, set of calibration weights and foreign coinage in case, coin chute, coin collecting apparatus, paper / metal / plastic / electronic components, TST International, Brisbane, Australia/New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority, 1989 - 2008 The manuals and notes are instruction manuals supplied by TST International to the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority for operation of the automated coin toll collection apparatus. The notes have been prepared by Roads and Traffic Authority technicians to assist in operation and repair of the equipment in situ. The computer and calibration unit consist of a desk top monitor, keyboard and mouse, custom computer hard drive, a custom built computerised calibration unit housed in an enamelled metal shell, and a set of weights representing each coin denomination. This apparatus was used to calibrate the coin collecting machines.

Object Title: Coin toll collecting apparatus used on the Sydney Harbour Bridge, 1989
Coin toll collecting apparatus used on the Sydney Harbour Bridge, including cabinet containing the coin mechanism and controllers, coin vault, local lane controller to operate exit lights, coin basket (3), Digital Equipment Corporation computer used to calibrate the coin validator device, patron fare indicator, exit light set, spare parts to maintain operation including pick-up wheels, actuators, escrow wheels, validators, solenoids, metal / plastic / electronic components, TST International, Brisbane, Australia/ Digital Equipment Corporation, United States of America, 1989 The coin collecting mechanism consists of a metal plate (platen) on which the coins are dropped by a feeder that leads from the collection basket. The platen spins and coins drop into slots specifically cut for each denomination. The coins are then given an electrical charge, which is read by a sensor. Because each denomination has its own signature, the coins are then verified and drop down into the vault. The vault sits beneath the coin collector, and consists of two coin drawers in a heavy case. The drawers have a one-way locking mechanism, closed when the drawer is removed from the vault case. The local lane controller is a switching device that is connected to the coin collection mechanism and the exit light that notifies the motorist when they may move from the toll plaza into traffic. The coin basket is a hard plastic funnel that sits on the outside of the apparatus and channels the coins into the coin mechanism. The fare indicator and exit light are electronically-lit sign boxes. The Digital Equipment Corporation computer coin validator device is of a ubiquitous PC appearance, though is a specialised computer.
Provenance (History): User: Roads and Traffic Authority of NSW; Sydney Harbour Bridge; 1989 - 2008|

A bell-shaped, mould-pressed earthenware white cup with black loop handle ('Coupe' shape) , one side transfer-printed (lithographed) with a design depicting a scene from a 1930s cruise liner: a stylised woman in blue trousers reclines on a deck chair while reading a book. A painter's palette shaped saucer with an oval hole for the thumb, is printed in the middle with another woman, wearing green trousers, white top and a green beret and lying down on a rug, reading a book. Object Title: Clarice Cliff 'Biarritz' dinner set, England, 1936 - 1938
Part dinner set, comprising one covered soup tureen and serving ladle, one covered vegetable tureen , one sauce bowl with ladle, one soup plate, one dinner plate, one dessert plate and one platter, 'Biarritz' range, shape pattern B29, earthenware, designed by Clarice Cliff, A J Wilkinson Ltd, Burslem, Stoke on Trent, Staffordshire, England, c 1936 1. A large, semi-spherical and flattened on two sides soup tureen in pressed white earthenware dipped in honey glaze, and with flat rectangular cover featuring a flattened circular finial and pierced to accommodate a matching serving ladle. The tureen stands on two cylindrical feet which run across base of tureen. Handpainted onglaze decoration on one side consists of an airbrushed mauve semi-circle outlined with curving light-brown band on the left and a simple floral motif - in fawn, rusty orange and black- on the right . Identical pattern occupies the outside, bottom right hand quadrant and the design is completed by the broad circular band which completes the circular pattern outside the well. 5. Matching rectangular soup plate with round well. 6. Matching rectangular dinner plate with round well. 7. Matching rectangular dessert plate with round well.

No. 784849 And (on some pieces including the large tureen) onglaze lithograped mark: 'HAND MADE/ Bizarre /by /Clarice Cliff/ WILKINSON LTD/ ENGLAND.' Incised 'V' on some pieces. Object Title: Barbie and the Rockers doll's playset, 1985
Doll's playset and packaging, 'Barbie and the Rockers', including stage, instruments and accessories, plastic / paper, made by Mattel Inc, Australia and United States of America, 1985 When set up, the playset has a black plastic floor, in two connecting pieces, with a silver glitter trim. On the back outside edges of the floor there are clips to insert the cardboard backdrops. One backdrop features an image of stars and spotlights. An arch attaches over the backdrop with the name 'Rockers' printed across it. The other backdrop features an image of a backstage room with dressing table and wardrobe. The arch that attaches over this backdrop features the image of spotlights. The accessories include a pink and a blue guitar, a pink keyboard, a stage light on stand, a TV camera on stand, and two pre-recorded audio cassettes. For the backstage setting the accessories are four hair brushes, four hand mirrors, and four chairs. There are also four doll stands, and one larger star-shaped stand. The set is complete in its packaging, the outer box of which features a photograph of the playset assembled and with dolls on the front, and diagrams of the two alternate assemblies on the back of the box.

Object Title: Doll's house, 1946
Doll's house, 'Charlaine' and furniture, timber / plastic, made by staff at 'The Sydney Morning Herald', for Elaine Sellers, the daughter of a Japanese POW, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1946 The timber doll's house sits on a large green painted timber board enclosed by a cream painted two rail fence. Access to the house is via a small front gate and path to the front door which is inset with coloured glass. Above the front door is a brass plate with the house name "Charlaine". The entrance porch has its own gable roof with barge boards which is attached to the main portion of the house, which also features a gabled roof and barge boards front and back. A gabled dormer window is set in the roof with a chimney behind it painted to resemble brickwork. The side path has a lattice gate. Behind the house is a small free-standing toilet with a gable roof and built-in toilet seat complete with a roll of toilet paper hanging from the door. The doll's house is open at the back and is divided into three rooms. Two have linoleum and the upstairs bedroom has a piece of carpet. The doll's house is fitted with a few pieces of furniture including a kitchen sink, stove and bed, as well as an electric light switch.
Provenance (Production): Maker: The Sydney Morning Herald; Sydney, New South Wales; 1946|

Object Title: Groom novelty doll, 1932
Groom novelty doll, celluloid, used to decorate the wedding car of John Toomey and Mary Canning, Hunters Hill, New South Wales, Australia, 1932, made in Japan, c.1932 The groom doll is made of painted celluloid. The eyes are forward facing and the head is not as large as on the bride doll. The arms are joined to the body with string while the legs are moulded together. The groom is dressed in a painted-on suit, with black trousers, tail coat and top hat, and red waistcoat, bowtie and shoes. He is carrying a brown-coloured cane in his left hand and wears a monocle on his right eye, the cord for which is the only fabric on the doll.
Marks: Just below the doll's neck at the top of the back are the letters "SK" in a diamond followed by "Made in Japan" in a curve below it.

Object Title: Bride novelty doll, 1932
Bride novelty doll, Kewpie-style, celluloid/fabric, used to decorate the wedding car of John Toomey and Mary Canning, Hunters Hill, New South Wales, Australia, 1932, made in Japan, c.1932 The bride doll features some of the classic Kewpie doll characteristics, including a moulded-plastic celluloid body with moveable arms attached with thread, and with outstretched fingers. The legs are moulded together. The body is round and childlike, with a protruding tummy. The short hair is moulded in plastic with a central curl in the middle of the forehead. The painted eyes are large with long lashes and look sideways and the lips are small and red. The doll is dressed in a wedding dress, probably home made, comprising a machine-made lace dress with a raw edge and a silk-like petticoat which has hand-crocheted work around the hem. The tulle veil is held onto the head with hat elastic through which faux pearls are threaded. The doll also has another row of faux pearls around her neck and is barefoot.
Marks: Just below the doll's neck at the top of the back are the letters "TS" in a triangle with a rising sun. The words "Made in Japan" appear below it.
Provenance (History): : unknown; Hunters Hill, New South Wales; 1932|

Object Title: Park drag coach, 1885 - 1886
Coach, horsedrawn, park drag, timber / metal / cotton fabric, made by Vial & Sons, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, probably 1886 A large four-wheeled enclosed carriage drawn by four horses, this example is capable of accommodating a driver and up to fourteen passengers with rear seat accommodation for two grooms. The "U" shaped body is suspended on two mail springs, the front and hind wheel and spring assemblies being joined by a perch. Two external dos-a-dos seats are mounted on the roof and one each on a front boot and hind boot which are used to store luggage and equipment for the road such as spare harness. The seats are upholstered in black vinyl, a close modern equivalent of the original leatherette trim. Non-original fittings include two coach lamps which were purchased by Mr Paul Greenaway. These were provided to add to the completeness and authentic appearance of the vehicle. The bodywork shows little sign of wear and appears to be mostly original. The wheels are mounted on common axles with hub caps. The spokes are staggered and the dished wheels are fitted with steel tyres. The coach is finished in brushed dark green and black paint. A pole and two swingle trees are provided for harnessing the hind horses but the spreader bar for the lead horses is missing. The interior is fitted with yellow ochre cloth button upholstery. Each window may be covered by a solid wooden panel shutter which slides up into place by means of a strap.
Marks: The brass hub caps bear the wording "VIAL & SONS BUILDERS SYDNEY" . The axle arms are stamped with the maker's name "Woodhead and Sons, Bradford, Yorkshire" with an emblem of an elephant and castle in a circle. Object Title: Sculpture of a griffin made by Wunderlich Limited, 1903 - 1916
Sculpture, griffin, embossed zinc, used in the Kings Cross Theatre, Kings Cross, Sydney, made by Wunderlich Limited, Redfern, New South Wales, Australia, 1903-1916. .A zinc sculpture comprising one zinc griffin sculpture comprising the face and head of an eagle combined with the body of a lion. Object Title: Silk scarf 'Achievement', Barack Obama series by Mirka Rozmus, Australia, 2008
Scarf, 'Achievement', hand-woven with hand-dyed Japanese silks, box of silk bobbins, certificate of originality, designed and made by Mirka Rozmus, Katoomba, New South Wales, Australia, 2008 The man's silk scarf, titled 'Achievement', is rectangular in shape and classic in style. It was designed by the weaver Mirka Rozmus and hand-woven in fine hand-dyed steel grey Japanese silk on a red, white and blue striped warp of hand-dyed Japanese silks of the same weight. The scarf is neatly finished with hand-twisted and knotted fringes. Accompanying the scarf is a small box containing wound bobbins of the red, white, blue and grey silks used to weave it. The box itself is linked to the scarf and the silks only by its current use as a handy container. The typed and signed 'Certificate for the Powerhouse Museum' from the artist Mirka Rozmus details the title, number, dimensions and date of completion of the work, and includes guarantees of originality and uniqueness and recommendations for handling.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Clyde Engineering Company Limited photographic negatives Granville, Sydney, 1880 - 1945
Photographic glass plate negatives (72), made by Clyde Engineering Company Limited, Granville, New South Wales, Australia, 1880-1945 Seventy two glass plate negatives, some in paper sleeves. Some of these photographs were used in James Murray's book on the history of Clyde Industries, 'Phoenix to the World' and cover significant events in the history of the company. The subjects covered include employees voting to give 1/- a week for 20 weeks to the H.M.A.S. Sydney fund, images of the management team at Clyde Engineering works, gold stamping batteries and boilers made by Hudson Brothers, interiors of the first aid room in the Clyde factory, the erection of the Rushcutters Bay engine and winding house for the Eastern Suburbs tram line, and the demolition of the original smoke stack at the Granville works. Most of the photographs are in good condition but there are a number of broken and cracked plates.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Michael Jackson 'Bad' crew jacket, 1987
Crew jacket, Michael Jackson 'Bad' world tour, wool / nylon / metal / leather, made by L P Designs, United States of America, 1987 The jacket has a woollen outer shell with leather sleeves and elasticised nylon cuffs. The inner lining is of thin nylon. It has metal press-studs for fastening the jacket closed. The jacket is black with the logo 'Bad' embroidered on the left breast. On the back centre of the jacket is an embroidered red banner with the words 'Michael Jackson', a logo beneath it in white with the image of Mr Jackson's legs performing a particular dance move popularised by him, and below that a blue embroidered banner with the words 'World Tour'.

Object Title: Armchair, designed by Gerrit Rietveld and made in Amsterdam, 1927
Armchair (beugelfauteuil) from the frame chair range (beugelstoel), with original receipt, plywood / steel / beechwood / paper, designed by Gerrit Rietveld, 1927, made by Metz and Co, Amsterdam, Netherlands, 1932 Armchair (Beugelstoel) with pair of silver painted tubular steel frames shaped to form legs and also support the white painted / lacquered one-piece plywood seat and back with curved ends top and bottom to provide lateral bracing, attached to tubular frame with small nuts and bolts along edge, and pair of solid beech timber arms bolted into two points of frame. Receipt from Metz and Co, Amsterdam, dated 29 July 1932, for eleven pieces of furniture including the beugelstoel ('Fauteuil Riteveld III'), to Mr F van Hattem.

Object Title: Hand bag by Issey Miyake
Handbag, 'PLEATS PLEASE', womens, polyester / metal, designed and made by ISSEY MIYAKE, Japan, early 1990s, owned by Gene Sherman, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, early 1990s-2007 Handbag formed from two squares of black polyester joined at bottom and sides, open at the top and finished with two gros grain handles. The black fabric sides of the bag are bonded on the inside with rigid equilateral triangular 'plates'. These plates or facets are laid out in regular interlocking rows, each piece seperated from the next by a border of unbonded fabric which acts as a flexible 'hinge' when the bag moves. A concealed zip is set down below the top opening of the bag. The lining is grey polyester. Inside a pocket has been applied to the lining.
Marks: There are two white fabric labels. The first one with text 'PLEATS PLEASE', and the 2nd one with text 'MADE IN JAPAN, PP17-AG621, POLYESTER, PRODUCT OF ISSEY MIYAKE INC'.

Object Title: Skirt by Yohji Yamamoto

The pleats are set in a waistband at the top and sewn down along the hem at the bottom to give a 'hobbled' effect on one side. Object Title: Skirt by Comme des Garçons, 1997
Skirt, womens, polyester / nylon, designed and made by Comme des Garçons Co. Ltd, Japan, 1997, (made for the Spring / Summer collection "Body meets dress-dress meets body" 1997), owned by Gene Sherman, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1997-2007. Skirt of black polyester, constructed with a short overskirt and longer underskirt. Both skirt layers have asymmetrical hem lines, with the highest point in front of the proper right leg and lowest behind proper left leg. The hems of both skirt layers are caught up under themselves giving a bubble effect. The fabric of the overskirt is constructed with diagonal bands of fine pleats. These rows of pleats cross each other at right angles to give the impression of checks. The fabric of the bottom layer is slightly transparent and composed of rows of protruding square bubbles. This underskirt is caught up at the hem to a lining of tulle netting. There is no waistband.
Marks: 4 white labels, COMME des GARÇONS, M, ES-10014M, SURFACE 100% POLYESTER, LINING 100% NYLON, COMME des GARÇONS CO. LTD, MADE IN JAPAN

Object Title: Dress designed by Yasumasa Morimura for Pleats Please Issey Miyake
Dress, womens, screenprinted and pleated polyester, 'Pleats Please Issey Miyake Guest Artist series No1: Yasumasa Morimura', for 'PLEATS PLEASE', designed by Issey Miyake and Yasumasa Morimura, made by ISSEY MIYAKE, Japan, 1996, (made for the Autumn/Winter collection 1996) owned by Gene Sherman, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1996-2007. Full-length, body hugging dress with high neckline and long sleeves made of finely pleated polyester. The front of the dress is decorated with a printed image of the designer's body fused with the upper body of a neo-classical beauty from the oil painting 'La Source' by the French artist Jean-Auguste Ingres (1780-1867) in the collection of the Musèe d'Orsay, Paris. The inverted torso of the artist, swathed in red open weave fabric, is joined to the torso of the naked female figure from 'La Source' who carries a water pot on one shoulder (from which water flows). The back of the dress is a dark green polyester, it is machine sewn and unlined.
Marks: There are two white fabric labels. First one with text: 'PLEATS PLEASE, GUEST ARTIST, SERIES NO 1, YASUMASA MORIMURA'; The second label with product and care information (with Japanese text on one side of the label): NO PP64-JH732, SIZE 4, MADE IN JAPAN, 100% POLYESTER, PRODUCT OF ISSEY MIYAKE INC

Object Title: Jacket by Issey Miyake
Jacket, womens, deer skin leather, designed by ISSEY MIYAKE, (made for the Autumn / Winter collection 1989), made in Hong Kong, 1989, owned by Gene Sherman, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1989-2007. Womens cropped and asymmetrical brown leather jacket. The proper right side is constructed with a sleeve and a lapel . The proper left side is constructed as a sleeveless band which wraps around the waist. The jacket is fastened at the waist on the front proper left with two woven leather buttons. The lapel is wide, on the right front waist it starts as a crease, as it travels up across the chest and over the shoulder it deepens to a fold. The lapel is held in place with woven leather buttons. At the back the lapel opens into a wide triangular flap above the waist band. The jacket is constructed with a yoke across the back shoulders. It is padded, lined and has shoulder pads. There is a hidden slit pocket at right chest level. Made for the 1989 Autumn / Winter collection. Worn by Dr Gene Sherman.
Marks: There are two fabric labels. One black label has text 'ISSEY MIYAKE', and another white fabric label has product and care instructions. MADE IN HONG KONG, NO.: EQ33019, SIZE M, PRODUCTS OF ISSEY MIYAKE INT'L INC

Object Title: Jacket by Issey Miyake, 1999
Jacket, 'PLEATS PLEASE', womens, pleated polyester, designed and made by ISSEY MIYAKE, Japan, 1999 (made for the Autumn / Winter collection 1999), owned by Gene Sherman, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1999-2007. Jacket of pleated pale silver-grey polyester. It has been constructed from two horizontal rectangles of fabric which have been sewn together at the long edge. This join spans the central portion of the fabric leaving the ends unjoined and falling free. The top rectangle of fabric has been folded over and at each end, has been sewn together to form a tube for sleeves. The sleeves are sewn closed to the point at which the two rectangles of fabric have been joined. This garment can also be worn as a short shawl-jacket or shrug.

Object Title: Shearer's bicycle, 1910 - 1940
Bicycle, 'Royal', safety type, fitted out as a shearer's bicycle with a swag, billy, tucker bag and canvas roll, metal / hessian / leather / canvas, maker unknown, [used in Australia], 1910-1940 A safety bicycle fitted out with camping equipment of the type which would have been used by shearers in the early twentieth century to ride betweeen the sheds. The bicycle is a diamond framed safety bicycle fitted with curved handle bars which have rubber hand grips fashioned from gas masks. It also has rat-trap pedals with serrated edges, and a blue-painted heavy-duty metal luggage carrier over the rear wheel. The seat is a wide sprung leather type, made by Brooks, with large coils springs front and rear. The bicycle is finished in red, with the remains of a transfer with the wording 'Royal'. It also has a back pedal brake, headlamp bracket and aftermarket securing lugs for a tyre pump. The bicycle is fitted out with items which would have been used by a shearer or itinerant worker including a swag or bed roll placed over the top tube and tied down along the front forks with a leather strap and string. Tied to the handle bars is a twisted rope to which is attached a hessian bag which hangs quite low beside the front wheel. Another folded piece of canvas is tied onto the rear carrier with rope. A billy can is tied to the rear spring of the saddle.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Monkey circus postcard, Taronga Park Zoo, 1948 - 1949
Postcard, sepia, showing a monkey on a miniature bicycle, paper, made by Taronga Park Zoo, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1948-1949 The postcard features an image of a monkey sitting on a miniature bicycle. The monkey is chained onto the bicycle and is resting its chin and hands on the handle bars. The bicycle has specially adapted rods instead of the usual pedals which probably made pedalling easier. It appears that the photo was taken on the special concrete arena opened at the Zoo in 1936. The photograph is a real photo postcard type, 3½ inches (8.9 cm) x 5½ inches (13 cm), finished in sepia colour, with a white border and the caption: Taronga Park Zoo, Sydney, Australia. handwritten in white at the bottom of the photograph.
Marks: Written on the front of the postcard in white, transfer from the negative, 'Taronga Park Zoo / Sydney, Australia' On the reverse side there is a blue ink stain in the top right hand corner.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Taronga Zoo; Sydney, New South Wales; 1948 - 1949|

Object Title: Cowboy dress ups, 1950 - 1980
Fancy dress costume, cowboy chaps, 'Roy Rogers King of the Cowboys, Dale Evans Queen of the West', fabric / plastic, maker unknown, probably Australia, 1950-1980 Chaps are protective coverings for cowboy's legs. They were tied over trousers but, unlike trousers, have no seat and are not joined at the crotch. The chaps are finished in black and white, are decorated with sheriff stars, and feature a holster pocket and ties for the waist, and fastened with a metal buckle at the back. There is a faint imprint of text and graphics on the black section of the chaps referring to Roy Rogers 'King of the Cowboys', Dale Evans 'Queen of the West'.
Marks: Faint imprint of image and text on the black section of the chaps, 'King of the Cowboys / Roy', 'Roy Rogers / Dale Evans / Trigger', 'Queen of the West / Dale'. On the reverse side of the right chap at the top in blue ink is written 'MP'. There is some mould on the black areas of the chaps. On the reverse side of the right chap there is a large dark stain. The left chap has three staples through it. One of the hanging sheriff stars is missing.

Object Title: Cowgirl dress ups, 1950 - 1980
Fancy dress costume components (3), consisting of cowgirl skirts (2) and an 'Annie Oakley' cowgirl waistcoat, fabric / plastic / vinyl, maker unknown, probably Australia, 1950-1980 There are three components in this set of children's dress up costumes comprising two skirts and a waistcoat. The two skirts are similar except one is long and the other short. They are made from printed cotton fabric in a 1950s full-skirt style with a waistband which features a printed pattern of horse heads and crossed revolvers framed within a twisted lasso. There is a plain central panel in red, and printed side panels which feature cowboys on horseback. There is a white fringe along the hems of both skirts. The waistcoat is also in a cotton fabric with vinyl inserts around the chest, with the stencilled wording 'Annie Oakley'. The waistcoat is finished in purple and grey and the chest is decorated with two sheriff-style, 6-pointed tin stars with red plastic rhinestones. Two layers of white fringing complement the waistcoat which is lined inside with red fabric and edged around the arm holes and down the front in yellow.

Object Title: Bench lathe and box, 1800 - 1810
Bench lathe with triangular bar bed, mandrel, tailstock with loose runner, hand rest with one tee, slide rest, attachment for converting lathe to back gear, foot wheel, and box, metal / wood, made by Henry Maudslay, England, c. 1805 Lathe consisting of various components with transportation box. The bar is made of cast iron. There is a long shallow notch in the bar just to right of neck, a poppit to clear the large chuck or workpiece and scars from cutting off of circular pouring gates or chucking pieces. The poppits for the mandrel are made of bronze. Their style corresponds to that of Lancashire clock lathes (but these are more commonly seen in iron) with mandrel carried between independent poppits fitted individually to the bar. The neck poppit has a steel plug with centre in, on the right face below the collar. The left poppit carries a plain runner for the tail of the mandrel, and a cock is screwed on to bear a screw, with lock nut, which urges the runner up. The runner is clamped in the same way as the tailstock runner. The mandrel and pulley are made of bronze with hardwood filling. No numerals seen. Numbers of divisions not counted. The cone has three steps with round-bottomed grooves suitable for 1/4 inch gut; these were turned round, and have not worn to that shape from vee grooves. Mandrel appears to be steel throughout with double-cone neck. The seat for the pulley is octagonal and tapered. The style of the pulley corresponds closely to that of a headstock signed Maudslay in the Institution of Mechanical Engineers (London). There is a brass sleeve on the tail of the mandrel, part of which has been cut up into a fine helix. The chuck is an American-style three inch three-jaw geared-scroll self-centring chuck, dating probably from the late 19th century. Loose poppit or tailstock has a reversible runner, with male and female centres. The poppit has some empty holes, indicating that other parts were once fitted to it. The Handrest locks to the bar in a way also reminiscent of Lancashire clock lathes: tightening the locking screw to lock the lower part to the bar also draws down a steel dovetail slip through two bolts which locks the slider to the lower part as well. The bronze slider is made up with separate jib pieces screwed or riveted with steel pins. The tee and its binding screw are steel. Several holes drilled into the lower block and into the slider, some tapped, indicate that other apparatus has been mounted to these parts. The slide rest, though unsigned, is undoubtedly by Maudslay and is of his usual pattern. The bronze base casting is clamped to the bed by steel bow nut and keeper. The lower slide has bronze gib pieces both sides which are adjustable, each having three setting-up screws and four binding screws which are numbered and correspond to numbers stamped adjacent to them. The slider is of cast iron. The steel lead screw is let in from above with caps that are flush, each held by two screws. The nut of brass or bronze is divided horizontally; the two parts united by two screws put in from below, and is fixed to the slider by two screws from above. The screw is very fine and extends to the rear about 13.5mm; this was intended to carry wheels for the screw-cutting apparatus with the slide mounted on a right angle extension piece (not present) so that this screw would be parallel to the lathe axis. This end of the screw now carries a brass or bronze worm wheel (36 teeth) 47.5mm in diameter. It was once secured by a cross pin, now absent. This would appear to be intended for an automatic feed to this motion of the rest, using other apparatus that is lost. The slider has six tapped holes on its centre line to receive the centre pin and binding screws of the upper slide. The centre pin is conical and has a slot for a screw driver. The upper slide has a bronze base which is capable of being set round to about 30 degrees each side of right-angles to the lower slide. The steel index mentioned above fits into two holes on the rear flange of this piece. Both gibs (bronze) are movable, secured b

Object Title: Sydney Telegraph newspaper obituary of Henry Chamberlain Russell, 23/02/1907
Letterpress and photo-mechanical print, obituary of Henry Chamberlain Russell, paper / ink, printed by Daily Telegraph, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 23 February 1907 An obituary for Henry Chamberlain Russell clipped from the Sydney Telegraph newspaper.
