Object Title: Storm card designed by Henry Chamberlain Russell, 1891
Ephemera, storm card, paper / ink, designed by Henry Chamberlain Russell, Sydney Observatory, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1891 A storm card consisting of a circular section on the right and a rectangular section on the left. The card is printed on both sides. One side is marked for use in the Northern Hemisphere, the other side for use in the Southern Hemisphere. Printed on each side of the circular section are the points of a compass.
Marks: Text on the card reads 'STORM CARD / FOR / NORTHERN HEMISPHERE / When you use this Card the arrow that / shews the direction of the wind then blowing; / suppose it is N.E, then place the arrow 4 on the ship's / position, taking care to make the "VANE" point to / North on the Chart / then from the ship, the bearing / of the storm centre is the same as the Card centre C, / ie South-East, and this holds true for any wind. / N.H. for North Hemisphere. With reference / to dotted arrows see envelope. / Sydney Observatory / 1891 / H C Russell / Astronomer'. Printed in the centre of the circular section 'VANE / NCH'. The reverse side reads 'STORM CARD / FOR / SOUTHERN HEMISPHERE / When you use this card the arrow that / shews the direction of the wind then blowing; / suppose it is N.E, then place the arrow 8 on the ship's / position, taking care to make the "VANE" point to / North on the Chart / then from the ship, the bearing / of the storm centre is the same as the Card centre C, / ie North-West, and this holds true for any wind. / S.H. for North Hemisphere. With reference / to dotted arrows see envelope. / Sydney Observatory / 1891 / H C Russell / Astronomer'. Printed in the centre of the circular section 'VANE / SCH'.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Russell, Henry Chamberlain; Sydney Observatory; 1891|
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: H10273-8 Astronomical model, lantern slide, phases of the Moon and tides, wood / glass / metal, made by Dollond, London, England, 1758-1856, used at Sydney Observatory, New South Wales, Australia, 1858-1900
Astronomical model, lantern slide, phases of the Moon and tides, wood / glass / metal, made by Dollond, London, England, 1758-1856, used at Sydney Observatory, New South Wales, Australia, 1858-1900. An astronomical model consisting of a rectangular wooden frame with a circular painted glass panel in the centre that demonstrates the phases of the moon and tides. The glass panel is contained within a brass frame with teeth around its edge, allowing it to be turned by a gear handle at one end of the wooden frame. Light shines through the glass plate and illuminates the model.
Marks: Label adhered to the top of the wooden frame reads 'This Diagram illustrates the (illegible)use (illegible)f Spring and Neap / Tides, and shews the Moon's Phases during its revolu(illegible)'.

The glass panel is contained within a brass frame with teeth around its edge, allowing it to be turned by a gear handle at one end of the wooden frame. Light shines through the glass plate and illuminates the model. The end of the handle has broken off and is missing.
Marks: A worn green label adhered to the bottom of the wooden frame reads 'A COMET. / Excentrically passing through the SOLAR SYSTEM - its tail invariably / being opposed to the SUN./ DOLLOND LONDON'.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: H10273-2 Astronomical model, lantern slide, phases of the Moon and tides, wood / glass / metal, made by Dollond, London, England, 1758-1856, used at Sydney Observatory, New South Wales, Australia, 1858-1900
Astronomical model, lantern slide, phases of the Moon and tides, wood / glass / metal, made by Dollond, London, England, 1758-1856, used at Sydney Observatory, New South Wales, Australia, 1858-1900. An astronomical model consisting of a rectangular wooden frame with a circular painted glass panel in the centre that demonstrates the phases of the moon and tides. The glass panel is contained within a brass frame with teeth around its edge, allowing it to be turned by a gear handle at one end of the wooden frame. Light shines through the glass plate and illuminates the model.
Marks: A worn green label adhered to the bottom of the wooden frame reads 'THE TIDES / Spring and Neap - occasioned by the attractive influence of the SUN / and MOON; also showing the Phases of the Moon. / DOLLOND LONDON'.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Wool specimen, stud ewe, bred by James Dalrymple Cox, Cullenbone, Mudgee, New South Wales, Australia, 1905 A wool sample from a stud ewe. The wool specimen is of a pure Mudgee type and of a growth of eight months. The wool is a natural cream and brown colour and there is dirt on the surface of the sample. A faded oval green tag with hand writing attached to a white cotton tie that accompanied the original specimen. There is also a white paper label with hand writing later added to the specimen. This sample of wool was tested in June 2007 by the Interactive Wool Group. They used the OFDA2000 instrument for fleece testing. The following are the results for this specimen: Microns: 22.4 microns (3.8 Standard Deviation) (average fibre diameter) Staple length: 55 mm Mean fibre curvature: 122.8 Dg/mm (A measurement in degrees per mm related to crimp frequency) Comfort Factor: 97.1 % (The % of fibres equal to or less than 30 microns)
Marks: Faded green oval tag reads F7949 / Stud Ewe / Mudgee on one side and the other side reads No 1. S.E Lowe / Mudgee'. White paper label reads 'STUD EWE 1905 / PURE MUDGEE TYPE 8 MONTHS / GROWTH L D COY / CULLEMBONE / PRESENTED BY W.E. LOWE / "WILBERTREE" MUDGEE NSW'.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Cox, James Dalrymple; Mudgee, New South Wales; 1905|
Categories: Specimens|Wool specimens|Animal Samples and Products|Textile Technology

There is a black ribbon around the middle of the specimen and a small green tag attached to the ribbon. This sample of wool was tested in June 2007 by the Interactive Wool Group. They used the OFDA2000 instrument for fleece testing. The following are the results for this specimen: Microns: 22.5 microns (4.3 Standard Deviation) (average fibre diameter) Staple length: 80 mm Mean fibre curvature: 105.9 Dg/mm (A measurement in degrees per mm related to crimp frequency) Comfort Factor: 95.2 % (The % of fibres equal to or less than 30 microns)
Marks: Green tag reads 'F6349 / Std Ram' and on reverse 'No 26 J Mack / Berrybank / Vic'.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Mack, Joseph; Lismore, New South Wales; 1899|
Categories: Wool specimens|Specimens|Animal Samples and Products|Textile Technology
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Two wool specimens from a stud ewe, 1898
Wool specimen, stud ewe, pure Vermont, bred by Samuel McCaughey, Coonong, New South Wales, Australia, 1898 Sample of fleece with fragment of blue ribbon and a green oval tag attached. This sample of wool was tested in June 2007 by the Interactive Wool Group. They used the OFDA2000 instrument for fleece testing. The following are the results for this specimen: Microns: 23.2 microns (4.9 Standard Deviation) (average fibre diameter) Staple length: 55 mm Mean fibre curvature: 107.2 Dg/mm (A measurement in degrees per mm related to crimp frequency) Comfort Factor: 92.6 % (The % of fibres equal to or less than 30 microns)
Marks: Small tag reads 'F5866 / std ewe / 4 tooth' on reverse 'No 73 / S McCaughey / Coonong'.
Provenance (Production): Maker: McCaughey, Samuel; Coonong, New South Wales; 1898|
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

A length of pink tape is tied around the middle of the specimen and a small oval green tag is tied to the tape. This sample of wool was tested in June 2007 by the Interactive Wool Group. They used the OFDA2000 instrument for fleece testing. The following are the results for this specimen: Microns: 23.9 microns (3.7 Standard Deviation) (average fibre diameter) Staple length: 85 mm Mean fibre curvature: 106.2 Dg/mm (A measurement in degrees per mm related to crimp frequency) Comfort Factor: 95.5 % (The % of fibres equal to or less than 30 microns)
Marks: Green tag reads 'F4936 / Flock / Ram' and on reverse 'No 40 / Collaroy / Merriwa'.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Collaroy Company Limited; Merriwa, New South Wales; 1896|
Categories: Specimens|Wool specimens|Animal Samples and Products|Textile Technology
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

There is a label with the specimen. This sample of wool was tested in June 2007 by the Interactive Wool Group. They used the OFDA2000 instrument for fleece testing. The following are the results for this specimen: Microns: 23.2microns (5 Standard Deviation) (average fibre diameter) Staple length: 60 mm Mean fibre curvature: 116.3 Dg/mm (A measurement in degrees per mm related to crimp frequency) Comfort Factor: 92.2 % (The % of fibres equal to or less than 30 microns)
Marks: Text on label reads '1896 / "Dense Golden Horn II" / SIRE "GOLDEN HORN II" / "TREASURE" "GOLDEN TOM" "SIR THOMAS II" / "OLD SIR THOMAS" DAM: PURE BELLEVUE STUD / EWE. WINNER 1ST PRIZE YOUNG 1895. / Bred by Hon. Jas. Gibson / Bellevue Tasmania'.
Categories: Specimens|Wool specimens|Textile Technology|Animal Samples and Products
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Wool specimen from wether, 1895
Wool specimen, wethers, bred by John Charles Manchee, Glen Moan, Willow Tree, New South Wales, Austalia, 1895 Sample of fleece tied with a black ribbon. A green oval tag is attached. This sample of wool was tested in June 2007 by the Interactive Wool Group. They used the OFDA2000 instrument for fleece testing. The following are the results for this specimen: Microns: 20.9 microns (3 Standard Deviation) (average fibre diameter) Staple length: 60 mm Mean fibre curvature: 148.6 Dg/mm (A measurement in degrees per mm related to crimp frequency) Comfort Factor: 99.5 % (The % of fibres equal to or less than 30 microns)
Marks: Green tag reads 'No 91 / J C Manchee / Glen Moan / NSW' and on reverse 'f4609 / wether'
Provenance (Production): Maker: Manchee, John Charles; Willow Tree, New South Wales; 1895|
Categories: Specimens|Wool specimens|Animal Samples and Products|Textile Technology
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

There is pink tape tied around the middle of the specimen and a small green tag attached to the tape. This sample of wool was tested in June 2007 by the Interactive Wool Group. They used the OFDA2000 instrument for fleece testing. The following are the results for this specimen: Microns: 19.6 microns (3.6 Standard Deviation) (average fibre diameter) Staple length: 55 mm Mean fibre curvature: 106.1 Dg/mm (A measurement in degrees per mm related to crimp frequency) Comfort Factor: 99 % (The % of fibres equal to or less than 30 microns)
Marks: Green tag reads 'F2365 / Ewe 7yrs' and on reverse 'No 36 / W & T Dickson / Yarrawin / NSW'.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Dickson, W & T C; Brewarrina, New South Wales; 1891|

Object Title: Model of Royal Navy Frigate H.M.S. "Maidstone"
Ship model, Admiralty Dockyard model, HMS "Maidstone", 28-gun, sixth rate, Coventry class frigate, wood / ivory, made by Stephen Bingle, Royal Naval Dockyard, Chatham, Kent, England, c. 1756 The model is thought to have been constructed of boxwood with ivory dead eyes, gantry, some railing, the steering wheel and the construction of the ship's bell. Part of the decks have been left out to show internal construction, including the design of the floor of the master cabin. Painted cherubs feature around the sides and stern of the model. The supporting base is decorated with gilt scrollwork. Two ivory columns support the frigate on the base. Other details include catheads, lanyards, gratings and a capstan. While the model was sent away for safe keeping during the Second World War, the rigging suffered some deterioration during storage. In 1944, George O. Ingledew made repairs to the model as follows: a new segment in the rim of the steering wheel and the wheel and standard was fixed to the deck; repairs and renewal to the guard rails on the quarter deck; repairs to the hand pump; a new platform in the main chains was made; and other items were fixed, including ladders, main companionway, porthole covers, platform for the capstan and various loose pieces. The scale is ¼ inch to 1 foot.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: 90/317-9 Architectural drawing, first floor and roof plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 7th September 1937
Architectural drawing, first floor and roof plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 7th September 1937 An ink drawing of the Acklands Hotel, on the corner of Queen and Moncur Streets, Woollahra. The drawing depicts the 'FIRST FLOOR PLAN' and the 'ROOF PLAN'. There is a border around the drawing and the title of the plan can be seen been at the bottom of the plan. Next to the title is a signature. Notations and measurements can be seen written in ink on the plan.
Marks: Title on the plan reads 'PROPOSED REBUILDING ACKLANDS HOTEL / CORNER MONCUR & QUEEN STREETS WOOLLAHRA / FOR MESSRS TOOTH & COMPANY LTD / SCALE ONE INCH EQUALS EIGHT FEET'. Signature next to title 'Cyril C Ruwald / FRIBA FRAIA / Architect / 9 Martin Place Sydney / 7th Sept 1937'. Written in the top right corner of the plan 'SHEET No 3'.

Object Title: 90/317-8 Architectural drawing, ground floor and basement plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 7th September 1937
Architectural drawing, ground floor and basement plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 7th September 1937 An ink drawing of the Acklands Hotel, on the corner of Queen and Moncur Streets, Woollahra. The drawing depicts the 'GROUND FLOOR PLAN' and the 'BASEMENT PLAN'. There is a border around the drawing and the title of the plan can be seen been at the bottom of the plan. Next to the title is a signature. Notations and measurements can be seen written in ink on the plan.
Marks: Title on the plan reads 'PROPOSED REBUILDING ACKLANDS HOTEL / CORNER MONCUR & QUEEN STREETS WOOLLAHRA / FOR MESSRS TOOTH & COMPANY LTD / SCALE ONE INCH EQUALS EIGHT FEET'. Signature next to title 'Cyril C Ruwald / FRIBA FRAIA / Architect / 9 Martin Place Sydney / 7th Sept 1937'. Written in the top right corner of the plan 'SHEET 2'.

Object Title: 90/317-77 Diazo print, alterations and additions Botany View Hotel St Peters, ink / paper, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 11 February 1938 and printed by the Commercial Copying Company, 28 Martin Place, Sydney, New South
Diazo print, alterations and additions Botany View Hotel St Peters, ink / paper, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 11 February 1938 and printed by the Commercial Copying Company, 28 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia A diazo showing alterations and additions to the Botany View Hotel, St Peters. A 'BASEMENT PLAN' 'GROUND FLR PLAN' 'FIRST FLR PLAN', 'SECTION AA', 'SECTION BB', 'ELEVATION TO KING ST' and 'ELEVATION TO DARLEY ST' are outlined in brown with sections coloured in brown, orange and green. Notations and measurements are also given in brown ink. The title of the drawing can be seen in the bottom right corner of the drawing.
Marks: The title reads 'ALTERATIONS& ADDITIONS TO THE BOTANY VIEW HOTEL / CNR PRINCES HIGHWAY & DARLEY ST ST PETERS / FOR MESSRS TOOTH AND COMPANY LTD'. Text to the left of the title reads 'SCALE / 1/8" to 1 foot / DATE / 11/2/39' and to the right of the title 'Cyril C Ruwald / A.R.I.B.A A.R.A.I.A / Architect / 9 Martin Place Sydney / [24].1.38'. Stamp on the back of the print reads 'COMMERCIAL / COPYING COMPANY PTY LTD / 28 MARTIN PLACE / SYDNEY / BLUES HELIOS / PHOTOSTATS / BLACLINES / DIAL / B 6403'.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Ruwald, Cyril; Sydney; 11/02/1938|Printer: Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd; Sydney|

Diazo print, proposed new front gates Barker College Hornsby, ink / paper, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 10 July 1933 and printed by the Commercial Copying Company, 8 Castlereagh St Sydney, New South Wales, Australia A diazo showing the proposed new front gates to Barker College in Hornsby. An 'ELEVATION', 'SECTION' and 'PLAN' are outlined in brown with sections coloured in brown, orange and green. Notations and measurements are also given in brown ink. The title of the drawing can be seen in the bottom right corner of the drawing and a handwritten note can be seen in the top right corner.
Marks: Title reads 'PLANS FOR / PROPOSED NEW / GATES TO THE / BARKER COLLEGE / SCALE: 1/2 INCH TO ONE FOOT / CYRIL C RUWALD A.R.I.B.A A.R.A.I.A / ARCHITECT 9 MARTIN PLACE'. Text below the title 'E.D.J 10.7.33'. Handwritten note reads 'This is the Drawing forming part of the contract / Signed between the undermentioned parties. Stamp on back reads 'COMMERCIAL COPYING COMPANY / Phone B. 6408 (2 lines) / AND AT / 422 COLLINS ST MELBOURNE / CASTLEREAGH ST SYDNEY' Handwritten in red pencil on the back of the print 'Barker / College / Gates'.

Diazo print, foundation and ground floor plan Bank of NSW Scone, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 20 November 1937, printed by Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd 28 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 16 December 1937 A diazo print showing the new premises for the Bank of NSW in Scone. 'SECTION AA', 'FOUNDATION PLAN' and 'GROUND FLR PLAN' are outlined in brown ink with sections highlighted in orange, red, green and yellow. Measurements, notations and the title of the drawing are also printed in brown in ink. There is a rectangular border around the drawings and a title written within the border below the drawings. A handwritten note in red ink and signatures can be seen in the top right of the print. There is a printers stamp on the back of the print.
Marks: Title reads 'NEW PREMISES KELLY STREET SCONE / FOR THE BANK OF NEW SOUTH WALES / SCALES 1 INCH EQUALS 8 FEET'. Further text to the left of the title reads 'SHEET No 1', '8 FT TO ONE INCH', 16/12/37' and to the right of the title 'Cyril C Ruwald / FRIBA, FRAIA / Architect / 9 Martin Place Sydney / 20.11.37'. Handwritten note 'Original Contract / This is one of the Drawings referred / to in the general Conditions of / Contract made out between and / signed by the undermentioned / parties this twentyfirst day of March 1938' Followed by 'FOR BANK OF NEW SOUTH WALES / [C Barret] / Proprietor / J E Parry / Contractor / [illegible] / Witness / [Diana Scott] / Witness'. Stamp on back reads 'COMMERCIAL / COPYING COMPANY PTY LTD / 28 MARTIN PLACE / SYDNEY / BLUES HELIOS / BLACLINES / DIAL / B 6403'.

Diazo print, New Premises site and drainage and footing plans Bank of NSW Port Kembla, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 10 September 1937, printed by Reproductions Pty Ltd, 28 O'Connell Street, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 12 November 1937 A diazo print showing the 'NEW PREMISES' of the Bank of NSW in Port Kembla. The 'SITE & DRAINAGE PLAN' and 'FOOTING PLAN' are outlined in brown ink with sections highlighted in orange and green. Measurements, notations and the title of the drawing are also printed in brown in ink. There is a rectangular border around the drawings and a title written within the border below the drawings. A handwritten note in red ink and signatures can be seen in the top right corner of the print. There is a printers stamp on the back.
Marks: Title reads 'NEW PREMISES CNR WENTWORTH & ALLAN STS PORT KEMBLA / FOR THE BANK OF NEW SOUTH WALES / SCALES 1 INCH EQUALS 8 FEET'. Further text to the left of the title reads 'SHEET No 1' and to the right of the title 'Cyril C Ruwald / FRIBA, FRAIA / Architect / 9 Martin Place Sydney / 10th Sep 1937'. Handwritten note 'This is one of the drawings referred to in the general / Conditions of Contract made out between & signed by / the undermentioned parties this twelfth day of / November 1937' Followed by 'FOR BANK OF NEW SOUTH WALES / [indecipherable signature] / Proprietors / A Collins / Witness' and 'ALEX MASTON LIMITED / Alex J Maston / Contractors / [indecipherable signature] / Witness'. Stamp on back reads 'COPIED BY / Reproductions / PTY LTD / ALL CLASSES OF COPYING WORK / 28 O'Connell / Sydney / Phones BW 1019 / BW 1010'.

Object Title: 90/317-4 Diazo print, poly chrome roof plan and sections Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, printed by Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd, 28 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Aust
Diazo print, poly chrome roof plan and sections Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, printed by Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd, 28 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 1st November 1937 A diazo print depicting the roof plan ('ROOF PLAN') and 2 sections ('SECTION "A"-"A" ' and 'SECTION "B"-"B" ') of Acklands Hotel, on the corner of Queen and Moncur Streets, Woollahra. The outline of the plan and each section is in brown and coloured in orange, yellow, red and blue. Notations handwritten in black ink can be seen in the top right corner of the print and additional notations handwritten in red ink can be seen down the right side of the print. There are signatures in black ink below the red ink notations. There is a rectangular border around the print and the title of the print can be seen within the border. There is a triangular red stamp on the back of the print.
Marks: The title of the print reads 'PLANS & SECTIONS SHOWING / ALTERATIONS OCCASIONED BY / REPLACING FIBROLITE ROOF / TO "ACKLANDS HOTEL" / WOOLLAHRA WITH TILES / SCALE ONE INCH EQUALS EIGHT FEET / 1.11.37'. Notations in black ink 'Omissions - omit two concrete flats as shown. / Omit brickwork above ceiling level to these / two features as shown. Reduce height of / brickwork to walls as shown on section "B"-"B" / omit all Fibrolite Flashing. Omit R.S.J nos 77, 78, 79, 80 & 81 & 76. Omit copper Hat / Omit all fibrolite roots. Omit flashing as / allowed where features projected through / roof. / Additions - Supply tile roof as indicated / sisalkraft sarking, wiring battens and all / incidentals connected with tiling. Supply / additional rafters as indicated together / with all other additional roof timbers shown / or as necessary supply / additional box quitters sumps & rainwater / heads to conform with fibrolite gutters etc / specified. Also supply to conform with original / specification such additional overflows & / other copper pipes as indicated. Provide / concrete capping to parapets where shown. / Note All parapets are 11" thick with full width / damp courses & properly flashed for 11" parapets specified.' Handwritten notation in red ink 'Note / It is hereby agreed that this variation to the Contract as required by the council be / made at an extra cost of [pound sign] 70.00 (seventy / Pounds) in accordance with the written / acceptance to the [Routractors]'. Below this is a stamp 'For Tooth & Co Limited / [illegible signature] / General Manager' followed by the signatures of the proprietor, the contractor and two witnesses. Stamp on the back reads 'COMMERCIAL / COPYING COMPANY PTY LTD / 28 MARTIN PLACE / SYDNEY / BLUES HELIOS / PHOTOSTATS / BLACLINES / DIAL / B6403'.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Ruwald, Cyril; Sydney; 01/11/1937|Printer: Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd; Sydney|
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: 90/317-32 Architectural drawing, alterations ground and first floor Scheme 2 Bank of NSW Nowra, paper / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 24 January 1939
Architectural drawing, alterations ground and first floor Scheme 2 Bank of NSW Nowra, paper / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 24 January 1939 A pencil drawing depicting the 'GROUND FLR PLAN' and 'FIRST FLR PLAN' of the Bank of NSW in Nowra. The drawing is in lead pencil, with sections of the plans highlighted in coloured pencil. Notations and measurements can also be seen in lead pencil. There is a title written in pencil below the drawing and a border drawn around the drawing.
Marks: Title of the drawing reads 'PROPOSED ALTERATIONS TO PREMISES AT NOWRA N.S.W / FOR THE BANK OF NEW SOUTH WALES / SCALES One Inch equals 8 feet'. Handwritten below the title 'Scheme 2 [Pound sign] 1700'. There is a signature in pencil above the title 'Cyril C. Ruwald / FRIBA, FRAIA / Architect / 9 Martin Place Sydney / 24.1.39'. Additional handwritten text on the plan reads 'This plan is to be read in / corporation with scheme No 1 / As to office is Living Rm notes only. / A G R'.

Object Title: 90/317-3 Diazo print, polychrome elevations and sections Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 9th November 1937
Diazo print, polychrome elevations and sections Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 9th November 1937 A diazo print depicting 2 elevations ('QUEEN ST ELEVATION' and 'MONCUR ST ELEVATION') and 2 sections ('SECTION "A"-"A" ' and 'SECTION "B"-"B" ') of Acklands Hotel, on the corner of Queen and Moncur streets, Woollahra. The outline of each elevation and section is in brown with details in orange, yellow, red and blue. There is a rectangular border around the print and the title of the print can be seen within the border. Notations handwritten in red ink can be seen towards the bottom right corner of the print and signatures in black ink can be seen below the notation.
Marks: Title of the print 'PROPOSED REBUILDING ACKLANDS HOTEL / CORNER MONCUR & QUEEN STREETS WOOLLAHRA / FOR MESSRS TOOTH & COMPANY LTD / SCALE ONE INCH EQUALS EIGHT FEET'. Handwritten in ink next to the title 'Cyril C Ruwald / FRIBA FRAH / architect / 9 Martin Place Sydney/ 7th 9th 37'. Handwritten notation in red ink 'This is one of the Drawings referred to in the General Conditions / Contract made out between and signed by the undermentioned / parties this ninth day of November 1937'. Below this is a stamp 'For Tooth & Co Limited / [illegible signature] / General Manager' followed by the signatures of three witnesses.

Object Title: 90/317-21 Architectural drawing, ground plan Albion Hotel Grabben Gullen, paper / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 60 Hunter Street, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 10 February 1948
Architectural drawing, ground plan Albion Hotel Grabben Gullen, paper / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 60 Hunter Street, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 10 February 1948 A pencil drawing depicting the 'GROUND FLOOR PLAN' of the Albion Hotel, in Grabben Gullen. The outline of the plan and notations are in lead pencil with sections of the walls coloured in yellow pencil. There is a rectangular border around the drawing and a title can be seen within the border below the drawing.
Marks: Title of the drawing reads 'GROUND FLOOR PLAN / MEASURED DRAWINGS "ALBION" HOTEL GRABBEN GULLEN / NEW SOUTH WALES / FOR L.J. SHEPHERD ESQ RE / SCALE ONE INCH EQUALS EIGHT FEET / CYRIL C. RUWALD F.R.I.B.A., F.R.A.I.A. ARCHITECT 60 HUNTER ST SYDNEY B.4734 11.2.48'. Handwritten text in the top right corner reads 'Measured 10.2.48 by C.C.R'. There is also a signature below the drawing 'Cyril C Ruwald / Architect'.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: 90/317-20 Architectural drawing, ground floor plan Albion Hotel Grabben Gullen, paper / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 60 Hunter Street, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia
Architectural drawing, ground floor plan Albion Hotel Grabben Gullen, paper / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 60 Hunter Street, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia A pencil drawing depicting the ground floor plan of the Albion Hotel, in Grabben Gullen. Object Title: 90/317-2 Architectural drawing, polychrome sketch elevation Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 3 July 1937
Architectural drawing, polychrome sketch elevation Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 3 July 1937 A pencil drawing depicting a sketch plan for the exterior of Acklands Hotel, corner of Queen and Moncur Streets, Woollahra. The drawing is on tracing paper and mounted on card. The outline of the building is in lead pencil with details shaded in red, yellow and brown. The sketch depicts foreground details including the road going past the hotel, people, cars, and a tram. A rectangular border has been drawn around the sketch and information about the sketch written within the border below the drawing. A signature and date can be seen in lower right corner of drawing handwritten in pencil.
Marks: Title handwritten beneath elevation in lead pencil reads 'SKETCH PLANS FOR ACKLANDS HOTEL CR QUEEN & MONCUR STS WOOLLAHRA / FOR TOOTH & CO LTD'. Signature of architect and date of illustration in lower right corner, handwritten in lead pencil 'Cyril C Ruwald / FRIBA FRAH / architect / 9 Martin Place Sydney / CCR 3.7.37'.

Diazo print, ground plan Albion Hotel Grabben Gullen, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 60 Hunter Street, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, printed by Burnside Copying Company, 5A Castlereagh Street, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 10 February 1948 A diazo print depicting the 'GROUND FLOOR PLAN' of the Albion Hotel, in Grabben Gullen. The outline of the plan, notations and marks are in black ink. There is a rectangular border around the print and the title of the print can be seen within the border below the drawing. The printers stamp can be seen in purple on the back of the print in the bottom left corner.
Marks: Title of the plan reads 'GROUND FLOOR PLAN / MEASURED DRAWINGS "ALBION" HOTEL GRABBEN GULLEN / NEW SOUTH WALES / FOR L J SHEPHERD ESQ RE / ONE INCH EQUALS EIGHT FEET / CYRIL C RUWALD F.R. I. B. A, F. R. A. I. A. ARCHITECT 60 HUNTER ST SYDNEY B4734 11.2.48'. Below the drawing is a signature 'Cyril Ruwald / Architect'. In the top right corner of the drawing "Measurement 10.2.48 by CCR'. The stamp on the back of the print reads 'BURNSIDE / COPYING COMPANY / BASEMENT / 5 A CASTLEREAGH ST / SYDNEY / PHONES / B 228 & B 2244'.

Object Title: 90/317-14 Diazo print, first floor and roof plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, printed by Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd, 28 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 7
Diazo print, first floor and roof plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, printed by Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd, 28 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 7 September 1937 A diazo print depicting the 'FIRST FLOOR PLAN' and the 'ROOF PLAN' for the Acklands Hotel, on the corner of Queen and Moncur Streets, Woollahra. The outline of each plan is in brown and details coloured in orange, grey, blue and brown. There is a rectangular border around the print and the title of the print can be seen within the border below the drawing. Notations handwritten in red ink can be seen down the left hand side of the print. The printers stamp can be seen on the back of the print in the bottom left corner.
Marks: The title of the plan reads 'PROPOSED REBUILDING ACKLANDS HOTEL / CORNER MONCUR & QUEEN STREETS WOOLLAHRA / FOR MESSRS TOOTH & COMPANY LTD / SCALE ONE INCH EQUALS EIGHT FEET'. The signature next to the title reads 'Cyril C Ruwald / FRIBA FRAH / Architect / 9 Martin Place Sydney / 7th Sept 1937'. Notation handwritten in red ink 'This is one of the Drawings referred to in the General Conditions / of Contract made out between and signed by the undermentioned / parties this ninth day of November 1937'. Below this is a stamp 'For Tooth & Co Limited / [illegible signature] / General Manager' followed by the signatures of the proprietors, contractors and two witnesses. The stamp from the printers office on the back of the plan reads 'COMMERCIAL / COPYING COMPANY PTY LTD / 28 MARTIN PLACE / SYDNEY / BLUES HELIOS / PHOTOSTATS / BLACLINES / DIAL / B6403'.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Ruwald, Cyril; Sydney; 07/09/1937|Printer: Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd; Sydney|

Object Title: 90/317-13 Diazo print, ground floor and basement plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 7 September 1937
Diazo print, ground floor and basement plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 7 September 1937 A diazo print depicting the 'GROUND FLOOR PLAN' and the 'BASEMENT PLAN' for the Acklands Hotel, on the corner of Queen and Moncur Streets, Woollahra. The outline of each plan is in brown and details coloured in orange, yellow, red and green. There is a rectangular border around the print and the title of the print can be seen within the border below the drawing. Annotations handwritten in red ink can be seen down the left hand side of the print.
Marks: The title of the plan reads 'PROPOSED REBUILDING ACKLANDS HOTEL / CORNER MONCUR & QUEEN STREETS WOOLLAHRA / FOR MESSRS TOOTH & COMPANY LTD / SCALE ONE INCH EQUALS EIGHT FEET'. The signature next to the title reads 'Cyril C Ruwald / FRIBA FRAH / Architect / 9 Martin Place Sydney / 7th Sept 1937'. Notation handwritten in red ink 'This is one of the Drawings referred to in the General Conditions / of Contract made out between the undermentioned parties / and signed this ninth day of November 1937'. Below this is a stamp 'For Tooth & Co Limited / [illegible signature] / General Manager' followed by the signatures of the proprietors, contractors and two witnesses. 'SHEET 2' is printed in the top right corner.

Object Title: 90/317-12 Diazo print, new garage plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, printed by Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd, 28 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 22 August 1
Diazo print, new garage plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, printed by Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd, 28 Martin Place, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia, 22 August 1938 A diazo print depicting the garage plan for the Acklands Hotel, on the corner of Queen and Moncur Streets, Woollahra. The 'FRONT ELEVATION', 'LONG SECTION', 'PLAN' and the 'BLOCK PLAN' are shown. The outline of each plan and section is in brown and coloured in orange, yellow, and green. A stamp containing a signature can be seen towards the top left corner of the plan and handwritten notations black ink can be seen across the print. There is a rectangular border around the print and the title of the print can be seen within the border below the drawing. On the back of the print there are two 'LOCAL GOVERNMENT' stamps and the printers stamp can also be seen in the bottom left corner.
Marks: Title of the plan reads 'NEW GARAGE FOR / WOOLLAHRA HOTEL WOOLLAHRA / Scale 1/8" equals 1'-0" '. Signature to the right of the title reads 'Cyril C Ruwald / FRIBA FRAIA / Architect / 9 Martin Place / Sydney'. Handwritten text in the 'BLOCK PLAN' reads 'Omit / Cyril C Ruwlad / for W A [Wethste]'. Stamped in top left corner 'Approved by the Council / Municipality of Woollahra / subject to the provisions of / Ordinance 71 / [signature J C Lough] / Town Clerk / Date 26/9/38'. The stamp from the printers office on the back of the plan reads 'COMMERCIAL / COPYING COMPANY PTY LTD / 28 MARTIN PLACE / SYDNEY / BLUES HELIOS / PHOTOSTATS / BLACLINES / DIAL / B6403'.
Provenance (Production): Maker: Ruwald, Cyril; Sydney; 22/09/1938|Printer: Commercial Copying Company Pty Ltd; Sydney|
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: 90/317-11 Architectural drawing, ground floor and basement plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place Sydney, New South Wales, Australia
Architectural drawing, ground floor and basement plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place Sydney, New South Wales, Australia An ink and pencil drawing depicting the 'BASEMENT PLAN' and 'GROUND FLOOR PLAN' of the Acklands Hotel, on the corner of Queen and Moncur Streets, Woollahra. There is a border around the drawing and the title of the plan can be seen been at the bottom of the plan. Notations and measurements can be seen written in ink and pencil on the plan.
Marks: Title of the drawing reads 'STEEL AND REINFORCED CONCRETE LAYOUT CROSS KEYS NEWCASTLE / SCALE 1"= 8'-0" '. 'CROSS KEYS NEWCASTLE' has been crossed out and 'Acklands Hotel Woollhra' written above it in blue pencil. A note written above the title reads 'Note All Bearings Connections / Rivets & Templates Are to be Supplied / by the Steel Companyof Sufficient Dimensions / & Strength to Transfer the Loads'.

Object Title: 90/317-108 Pencil drawing, polychrome, perspective elevation, "Seven Dwarfs Inn", Canterbury Hotel (Woolpack Hotel), Canterbury. Cyril Ruwald, Sydney, Australia 1940
Pencil drawing, polychrome, perspective elevation, "Seven Dwarfs Inn", Canterbury Hotel (Woolpack Hotel), Canterbury. paper, Cyril Ruwald, Sydney, Australia 1940. Pencil drawing on tracing paper, elevation within pencil border, outline of building in lead pencil, details shaded in red, yellow and green. Depicts an alternate elevation of corner of hotel, with text by Ruwald explaining design. "By introducing a hooded corner treatment supported on piers; figures on gargoile could pleasingly surmount each pier. The figures might take the form of seven dwarfs hence the suggested name "Seven Dwarfs Inn" Signed and dated by the architect in the lower right corner.
Marks: Comments on plan made by architect, handwritten beneath elevation in lead pencil, "ALTERNATE ELEVATION OF CORNER/ BY INTRODUCING A HOODED CORNER TREATMENT SUPPORTED/ ON PIERS; FIGURES OR GARGOILES COULD PLEASINGLY SURMOUNT/ EACH PIER./ THE FIGURES THAT MIGHT TAKE THE FORM OF SEVEN DWARFS/ HENCE THE SUGGESTED NAME 'SEVEN DWARFS INN'/ WOOL PACK HOTEL CANTERBURY", Signature of architect and date of illustration on lower right corner, handwritten in lead pencil "Cyril [illeg signature] Ruwald/ FRIBA FRAIA/ [illeg handwriting]/ 5/3/40".
Provenance (Production): Maker: Ruwald, Cyril; Canterbury, New South Wales; 05/03/1940|
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: 90/317-10 Architectural drawing, first floor plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place Sydney, New South Wales, Australia
Architectural drawing, first floor plan Acklands Hotel Woollahra, paper / ink / pencil, Cyril Ruwald, 9 Martin Place Sydney, New South Wales, Australia An ink and pencil drawing depicting the 'FIRST FLOOR PLAN' of the Acklands Hotel, on the corner of Queen and Moncur Streets, Woollahra. There is a border around the drawing and the title of the plan can be seen been at the bottom of the plan. Notations and measurements can be seen written in ink on the plan.
Marks: Title on the plan reads 'FIRST FLOOR PLAN / STEEL & REINFORCED CONCRETE LAYOUT / FOR / ACKLANDS HOTEL WOOLLAHRA / SCALE 1" EQUALS 8'.0'. Notations to the left of the title 'NOTE: All bearings connections. / Rivets & Templates Are to be supplied / by the Steel Company: of sufficient / Dimensions & Strength to Transfer the Loads.'
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: 90/317-1 Architectural drawing, polychrome sketch interior perspective, proposed Tea Rooms (basement) ABC Bank, paper / pencil / [watercolours], Cyril Ruwald, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia
Architectural drawing, polychrome sketch interior perspective, proposed Tea Rooms (basement) ABC Bank, paper / pencil / watercolours, Cyril Ruwald, Sydney, New South Wales, Australia A pencil drawing on paper with sections highlighted in blue, red, brown and grey [watercolours]. The sketch shows the proposed interior for the tea rooms of 'ABC Bank' and features a room with black and white tiles on the floor and decorative wallpaper. There is a large circular chandelier hanging towards one side of the room. Five sets of tables and chairs can be seen. Figures have been drawn sitting at the two of the tables. Other figures can be seen standing in the room. A rectangular border has been drawn around the sketch and information about the sketch written within the border below the drawing. A signature can be seen in the bottom right corner of the sketch.
Marks: Handwritten text at the bottom of the drawing reads 'A.B.C BANK PREMISES PITT ST / PROPOSED TEA ROOM (BASEMENT) / SKETCH ONLY'. The signature is possibly the initials 'CCR'.
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of railway passenger carriage 2115
Photographic glass plate negative, second class 'Bradfield', Sydney suburban, railway passenger carriage No. 2115, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1921 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The plate is showing a second class 'Bradfield', Sydney suburban, railway passenger carriage No. 2115, Code E.F.A, for New South Wales Government Railways (N.S.W.G.R). The 1921 EBB/EFA suburban cars were designed by E.E. Lucy with 42 carriages built by Clyde. This carriage was delivered to (N.S.W.G.R) in November 1920 and went into service in January 1921, initially in steam service but from rail system. Ref. Cooke, David et al " Coaching Stock of the Railways Volume 1", Eveleigh Press, Matraville, NSW 1999. The plate is broken.

Object Title: Photograph of Avro Anson N4876 on lorry

Object Title: Photograph of American suburban railway passenger carriage
Photographic glass plate negative, American suburban railway passenger carriage [No. 1078], Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1912 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a bogie platform end from a first class railway passenger carriage No. 1078. The carriage is stationed in an outdoor setting on a set of railway tracks next to an industrial building. This type of carriage is known as a high elliptical roof American car, all timber construction, contract No 16/11, from New South Wales Government Railways (NSWGR) first class sitting car. Carriage is service April 1912 and condemned December 1974. Ref. "Coaching Stock of the Railways, Volume 1", Eveleigh Press, Matraville, NSW 1999.
Marks: There is black hand written text on the bottom middle of the plate which states the number of the negative, 'No 684'
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of a Fay Automatic Lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for machining one piece differential case, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for machining one piece differential case. The plate is accompanied by handwritten text on paper sleeve which reads '1457 (Fay 3882) / General View of a 20 x 28 Fay Automatic Lathe tooled for machining one piece / differential gear case #369951. This casting finishes 1 1/16" long & / flange is 7 1/2"{theta}. It is held on an electric chuck gripping on O.D. of / the flange. The carriage turns the 5 7/16" ring gear pilot & 5 3/8 relief. / Back arm faces the ring gear flange. A cat head carried by the / tailstock ram & another operated through the spindle bores, turns, / butt faces the end & chamfers the hole on both ends. All / tools cut together. / Taken 13-2-39 {initialed KW}'.
Marks: There is handwritten white ink text on the original copy which reads, ' 1457 / 3882' in the corners of the plate.
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of Fay Automatic Lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for third operation on one piece differential case, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for third operation on one piece differential case. There is handwritten text on paper sleeve which reads '1456 (Fay No 4009) / General View of a 12 x 15" Fay Automatic Lathe tooled for 3rd operation / on one piece differential case #300785. This case is 7" long & the / flange is 7 1/2"{theta}. It is held in centers locating in the chamfers in the / axle shaft holes & driven by a driver engaging in the large cored / holes in the side. Three micrometer adjustment carriage tools / finish turn the two bearing diameters & the ring hear pilot, while / 3 back arm tools are facing the 3 shoulders. / Taken 13-2-39 {initialed KW}'.
Marks: There is handwritten white ink text on the original copy which reads, ' 1456 / 4009' in the corners of the plate.
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of Fay Automatic Lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for first operation on bevel stem pinions, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for first operation on bevel stem pinions. There is handwritten text on paper sleeve reads '1455 (Fay No 4147) / General View of a 12 x 15 Fay Automatic Lathe tooled for 1st operation / on bevel stem pinions #52755-HA, 52727-HA & 52759HA. These / pinions are 9" long & have major diameter 3". The stem is about / 2"{theta}. Two carriages turn the O.D. using a taper turner for the gear / diameter, while the back arm chamfers four different diameters. The pinion is held between centres & driven by a 2-jaw / eccentric fixture. By using a spindle speed of 87 RPM & .023 / carriage turning feed, a floor to floor time of 1 min 48 secs. / is obtained which is 26 pinions per hour after allowing / 25% for extras. / Taken 13-2-39 {initialed KW}'.
Marks: There is handwritten white ink text on the original copy which reads, ' 1455' in the bottom corner of the plate.
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of Fay Automatic Lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for second operation on bevel stem pinions, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for second operation on bevel stem pinions. The plate is accompanied by handwritten text on paper sleeve which reads '1454 (Fay No 4149) / General View of a 12 x 15 Fay Automatic Lathe tooled for second / operation on bevel stem pinions # 52755-HA. Two carriages are used for turning the O.D. while the back arm faces / chamfers & necks to complete the operation. The pinion is held / between centers using a spring loaded headstock center & taking / a location with a locating fixture mounted on the carriage / against the side of the gear diameter. A taper turner is used on / one of the carriages for turning gear diameter. By using 156 spindle / RPM & .011 carriage turning feed a floor to floor time of 1 min; / 45 secs. is obtained per piecce which is a production of 27 pieces / per hr. after allowing 25% extras / Taken 13-2-39 {initialed KW}'.
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of Fay Automatic Lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for first operation on bevel ring gear, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for first operation on bevel ring gear. The plate is accompanied by a paper sleeve with handwritten text which reads '1453 (Fay No 4164) / General View of 20 x 16 Fay Automatic Lathe tooled for 1st operation on bevel / ring gear #52756-H. This forging is 12 1/2" {theta} 2" wide & has 6 5/8" hole through / it. It is held in a three-jaw air operated chuck. The carriage rough / & finish bores the hole, back faces inside of web, chamfers both / sides of the hole, while back arm rough faces & chamfers back / of gear. During this time the overhead slide finish faces back of the / gear, the overhead slide tool following the back arm tool very closely so / as to finish at same time. By using 28 RPM spindle speed a floor to / floor time of 2 minutes 59 secs. is obtained which is a production of / 16 ring gears per hour after allowing 25% for extras / Taken 13-2-39 {initialed KW}'.
Marks: There is handwritten white ink text directly on the plate which reads, '1453 / 4187'.
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of Fay Automatic Lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for second operation on bevel ring gear, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The images depicts a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for second operation on bevel ring gear. The plate is accompanied by handwritten text on a paper sleeve which reads '1452 (Fay No 4187) / General View of a 20 x 16 Fay Automatic Lathe tooled for second / operation on bevel ring gear #52758. The gear is held on an air / operated spindle fixture locating in the hole & driven by pins engaging / holes in the web. The carriage rough & finish turns O.D. of gear & / bores & chamfers under the teeth, while the back arm rough faces / the tooth angle & chamfers both ends of the O.D. & the overhead slide / finish faces the angle. All tools finish at same time. A bevel / facing attachment is used for controlling the back arm during / its cut. By using 28 RPM spindle speed a floor to floor time of / 2 minutes & 52 secs. is obtained which is 16 ring gears per hr. / - allowing 25% extras / Taken 13-2-39 {initialed KW}'.
Marks: There is handwritten white ink text directly on the plate which reads, '1452 / 4187'.

Object Title: Photograph of Fay Automatic Lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for turning both ends of axle shaft, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate in landscape format. The image depicts a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for turning both ends of axle shaft. The plate is accompanied by handwritten text on a paper sleeve which reads '1450 (Fay No 4303) / Close View of the tooling on a 12 x 45" Fay Automatic Lathe tooled for turning / both ends of Axle Shaft No. 316674. This shaft is approx. 1 1/2" {theta} & 32 1/2" long. / It is mounted on centers & driven by a 3-jaw driving fixture mounted on / a center drive attachment. Tools mounted on the carriages turn both ends / the taper portion being generated by a carriage controlled by a taper / former. The back arms face, form & chamfer wherever necessary using / and end cut form tool, for forming, necking & chamfering the thread / diameter. By using a spindle speed of 266 RPM a floor to floor / time of 1 minute, 5 seconds is obtained which is a production of / 44 shafts per hour after allowing 25% for extras. / Taken 13-2-39 {initialed KW}'.

The back arm rocks in carrying 3 tools which / face end of drum, form first groove & diameter adjacent to it. also chamfer end / of drum. Cemented carbide tipped cutting tools are used in the cat head & back / arm tool blacks. Boring tools in boring bar are high speed steel. The carriage rough turns the O.D. cam / turning the relief under the wrist pin bosses while the auxiliary / slide is rough facing the head & rough forming the ring grooves. / The carriage then forms the O.D. of the ring lands & chamfers them / Then the carriage finish cam turns the O.D. while the back arm / is finish facing the head. Then the the back arm finish forms / the ring grooves & chamfers the skirt & head. Cemented / Carbide tipped tools are used. Then the / back arm rocks in carrying five end cut tools and finish faces & chamfers both / and & finish straddle faces the flange & fin portion, also finish forming the diameters adjacent to them. / By using a 28 RPM spindle speed & .0018 carriage turning feed for roughing 7 / 14RPM and .005 back arm finish facing speed a floor to floor time of 4 minutes, 26 s / is obtained which is 10 pieces per hr. after allowing 25% for extras. / the cylinders come to this operation with the hole finished bored & they are held . by hydraulically operated fixtures on both the spindle & tailstock ram. Endwise / location is obtained by means of a swinging arm carrying a plate which / locates from the flange. / Taken 9-2-39 / {initialled KW}'.
Marks: There is handwritten white ink text directly on the photograph which reads, '1415' in one corner and '4114' in the other corner.

All three banks of tools cut simultaneously so that by using . A spindle speed of 14 RPM a floor to floor time of 15 minutes, 48 seconds is / obtained which is an hourly production of 3 cylinder barrels per machine ./ after allowing 25% extras. / Taken 9-2-39 / {initialled KW}'.

Object Title: Photograph of Fay Automatic Lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for rough turning, facing & grooving aircraft piston, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, tooled for rough turning, facing & grooving aircraft piston. The plate is accompanied by a paper sleeve with handwritten text which reads '1410 ("Fay No" 4251) / Close View of the tooling on an 8 x 15" Fay Automatic Lathe / tooled for rough turning, facing & grooving airplane piston / # 28562. this is an alumin alloy piston 3 3/8" lg & 5 1/16 {theta}. It comes / to this operation with skirt end faced and bored. It is held / on an air operated fixture locating in this bore & against the / end & driven by a pin inserted in the wrist pin hole. / Carbide tipped tools are used. The carriage rough turns / the O.D. while the back arm faces the closed end & rough / forms the ring grooves, also rough forms the short diameter between / bottom ring groove and end of skirt. The tool in the back arm which / faces the head end is controlled by an automatic relieving attachment, which / relieves it on the return stroke so that it will not score. By addition / of tools on the carriage for chamfering the ring grooves & tools on the / back arm for forming the slight tapers above and below the ring grooves / & forming the radius on the skirt end of the piston, and also, changing / the ring groove tools and spacers, a finish turning and grooving operation / is performed on this dame piston on this machine in a manner similar to / the roughing operation. By using a spindle speed of 578 RPM & a carriage turning feed of .023, a floor to floor time of 31 secs is obtained per piston, which is an hourly production of 93 pistons, after allowing 25% for extras.'
Marks: There is handwritten white ink text directly on the photograph which reads, '4251' in two places.
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of Fay Automatic Lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, blade mounted in special clamp, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in portrait format. The image depicts a copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, blade mounted in special clamp. The plate is accompanied by a paper sleeve with handwritten text on which reads '1407 ("FAY NO" 4394) / Close View of tooling on a special 20 x 37" Fay Automatic / lathe for M/C Propellor Blade no 1. The hub on this aluminium / blade is 7" {theta}. It is held in special clamping fixtures, one / mounted on each side of the special center drive attachment. / An air operated headstock center supports the hub. The carriage rough turns the O.D. & generates the taper, using a taper turner / on the taper portion. During this time an auxiliary / slide mounted on the back arm rough forms & faces the hub with 3 tools. The the carriage returns and comes forward / again to finish turn the taper portion and O.D. while the / back arm rocks in to finish form the radius and the two / chamfers and short straight portion on the end of the hub. / Using spindle speed 168 RPM for rough & finish turning / & rough & finish facing. Then reducing spindle speed to / 84 RPM for finish forming, a floor to floor time of / 4 min 50 secs is obtained which is a production of 9 1/2 propellor blades per hr. after 25% for extras. The / spindle speed is changed by using a two speed electric / motor.'
Marks: There is handwritten white ink text directly on the photograph which reads the numbers, '1407' and '4394'.
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of Fay Automatic Lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, copy print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a copy of a print of a Fay Automatic Lathe, showing spider for a two blade prop. Object Title: Photograph of a 'Farmer's and Dairymens Milk Company Limited' louvred van
Photographic glass plate negative, 'Farmers and Dairymen's Milk Company Limited' louvered van number 5, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1900-1945 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in a landscape format. The image depicts a 'Farmers and Dairymen's Milk Company Limited' louvered van number 5. This four-wheel, timber bodied, steel framed louvered van was generally similar to a New South Wales Government Railways (N.S.W.G.R.) LV van, used for the transport of milk in cans. The image includes a group of railway wheel tyres in background. There is some damage to the plate. The van has external writing on the side which reads, 'FARMERS & / MILK' on one side of the van and 'DAIRYMENS / COY. LTD. NO. 5.' The van is stationed in an outdoor landscape setting next to an industrial building.
Marks: There is black hand written text on the negative in the middle bottom of plate stating 'No. 604'

Object Title: Photograph of bogie bolster wagon, number 100
Photographic glass plate negative, New South Wales Government Railway (N.S.W.G.R.) bogie bolster wagon, number 100, built by Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1900-1945 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landsacpe format. The image depicts New South Wales Government Railway (N.S.W.G.R.) bogie bolster wagon, number 100. It was built by the Clyde Engineering Co. and as it lacks buffers, and is equipped with knuckle couplers, it is likely that it was built for the Commonwealth Railways. At this stage, they were the only Australian railway operating bufferless rolling stock. The number '100' is on side frame. There are two men standing beside the wagon wearing suits and hats.

Object Title: Photograph of railway brake van, No.4, built for Colonial Sugar Refinary Company

The image depicts railway brake van, number 4, built for Colonial Sugar Refinary Company's Rarawai-Kavanagasau Light Railway in Fiji. The brake van was made to fit the Rarawai-Kavanagasau Light Railway 2'0" gauge narrow gauge and formed part of that railway's 'Free Train. It is fitted with a lifting frame to enable handling by overhead crane or derrick. The image of the van displays a rectangular cabin with hand rails on the outdoor section. Object Title: Photograph of Fay automatic lathe
Photographic glass plate negative, Fay automatic lathe tooled for rough finish straddle, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1939 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image on plate number 1434 depicts a Fay automatic lathe tooled for rough finish straddle. Annotation on sleeve reads; 'Fay number 3892. General view of an 8 x 15 automatic lathe tooled for rough finish straddle facing pitman shaft housing # 261893. This housing is 3 3/4 long and has an irregular shafted flange which has mix. Radius 2 15/16. It is held on plug centres and driven by two air operated floating jaws which grip the shank. The carriage rocks straight in rough facing both sides of the flange and back arm finish faces directly behind the carriage in same time. 'J' metal Satellite tools are used for roughing and HSS tools for finishing. By using 104 R.P.M. and .026 feed & floor to floor time of 56 secs is obtained. Taken 10-2-39.'
Marks: There is handwritten white ink text on the bottom corner of the plate which reads the plate number '1434'.

Object Title: Photograph of a model of the first locomotive built by Clyde Engineering
Photographic glass plate negative, silver model of New South Wales Government Railways [N.S.W.G.R.] T class locomotive No.356, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1907 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a silver model of New South Wales Government Railways [N.S.W.G.R.] T class locomotive No.356 later 5096, delivered in June 1907. This model is of Clyde Engineering's first locomotive and was reportedly presented to Joseph Carruthers who became New South Wales Premier in 1904. Object Title: Photograph of a four-wheel bogie for tank locomotive "Iron Duke"
Photographic glass plate negative, four-wheel bogie for tank locomotive "Iron Duke", Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1900-1950 This photograph depicts the four-wheel bogie for tank locomotive "Iron Duke"'. This locomotive was based on the New South Wales Government Railways S class suburban tank engine and was built by Clyde for the Australian and Steel Company to work its Spring Hill to Cadia iron stone railway in central-western New South Wales. This locomotive differed in several significant ways from the S class, including the use of outside-bearing trucks, as pictured.

Object Title: Photograph of a steam locomotive 5701
Photographic glass plate negative, steam locomotive 5701, designed by New South Wales Government Railways, Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1929 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a D57 railway steam locomotive 5701, designed by New South Wales Government Railways (N.S.W.G.R.). This was the first of 25 of these locomotives produced by Clyde Engineering. The tenders were built by Mort's Dock and Engineering Company, The first 'Mountain' Type locomotive it was designed by (N.S.W.G.R). Many served on the Illawarra line and electrification and their size caused many to be withdrawn from other lines in the mid 1950s. entered service 6 September 1929 withdrawn from service in November 1960 and scrapped on 15 November 1963 having travelled 1012,198 miles. It had a combined weight of 226 tons 3cwt. References; Turner, M., Australian Steam Locomotives; 1896-1958.
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of 4-6-4 side tank locomotive 'Iron Duke'
Photographic glass plate negative, 4-6-4 side tank locomotive 'Iron Duke', Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1920 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a 4-6-4 side tank railway steam locomotive labelled 'IRON DUKE'. This locomotive was built by Clyde Engineering, works number 242, for Hoskins Iron and Steel Company Limited of Lithgow, to work its ironstone branch line from Spring Hill to Cadia in central-western New South Wales. Built in 1920 the design was based on the New South Wales Government Railways (N.S.W.G.R.) S class tank engine, but there were major differences which included bar frames, a narrower firebox, a drumhead, an extended smokebox and outside bearing trucks. A clerical error was apparently made by an employee of Clyde Engineering in 1920 who assigned the same works (builder's) no. of 242 to two locomotives built by the company in 1920. One was the 'Iron Duke', and the other was No 1355 (later 5503) for the New South Wales Government Railways, (N.S.W.G.R.).
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.

Object Title: Photograph of 4-6-4 side tank locomotive 'Iron Duke'
Photographic glass plate negative, 4-6-4 side tank locomotive 'Iron Duke', Clyde Engineering Pty Ltd, Australia, 1920 A rectangular black and white silver gelatin glass plate negative in landscape format. The image depicts a 4-6-4 side tank railway steam locomotive labelled 'IRON DUKE'. This locomotive was built by Clyde Engineering, works number 242, for Hoskins Iron and Steel Company Limited of Lithgow, to work its ironstone branch line from Spring Hill to Cadia in central-western New South Wales. Built in 1920 the design was based on the New South Wales Government Railways (N.S.W.G.R.) S class tank engine, but there were major differences which included bar frames, a narrower firebox, a drumhead, an extended smokebox and outside bearing trucks. A clerical error was apparently made by an employee of Clyde Engineering in 1920 who assigned the same works (builder's) no. of 242 to two locomotives built by the company in 1920. One was the 'Iron Duke', and the other was No 1355 (later 5503) for the New South Wales Government Railways, (N.S.W.G.R.).
Categories: Glass plate negatives|Gelatin dry plate negatives|Photographs
License info: This text content licensed underCC BY-SA.
